PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to his diverse positions on the New South Wales police tapes, namely, that he found it difficult to make a decision on the matter because he was being given conflicting advice, that the police involved were not entitled to indemnity, and that the matter of indemnities is an unresolved question. Given that the fight against crime has been impeded for months because of the Attorney-General's seeming inability, at least to date, to come to a decision, will he now give the House an assurance that indemnities will be given so that the fight against organised crime can proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is most anxious that the fight against organised crime always proceeds. The Leader of the Opposition will recall that Mr Justice Stewart's commission related to the authenticity of material gathered from 1976 to 1981 when the honourable gentleman's Party was in power. Of course, as the information was then available one must ask what happened about the pursuit of organised crime in that period. Let me make it very clear that the period the honourable gentleman is talking about concerns his period of office.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly there are matters now before me relating to whether it would not be appropriate to consider indemnities. I have had the difficulty of Mr Temby saying that in those particular circumstances an indemnity should not be given. There is the added position that any evidence given to the Royal Commissioner cannot be used against the person giving it, in the sense of a prosecution. In other words, admissions made to the Royal Commissioner could be used in evidence. Nevertheless, the police concerned have requested indemnities. I propose tomorrow to see again Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby together to see whether we can reconcile that situation because I think there is new matter developing. That is the thrust of the honourable gentleman's question. There is new matter. We are very anxious to ensure that all criminals are brought to justice. So my view, even though I have not had a chance to discuss it with Mr Justice Stewart, is to say that, wherever he is of the opinion that evidence can be obtained that would lead to the prosecution of any criminal and he recommends an indemnity, I see no reason why I should not give it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy explain why the import parity price for indigenous crude oil has not fallen along with the prices of overseas crude oils, thus resulting in lower petroleum prices in Australia?

—Crude oil prices overseas have fallen only in United States dollars. Recently the fall in the Australian dollar relative to the United States dollar has more than offset the reduction of the price of overseas crude oils. Therefore, lower retail petrol prices have not been possible at this time. We are not Robinson Crusoe in that either. Many other oil importing countries have had similar experiences. The Government has been consistent in applying the import parity pricing policy and did reduce Australian prices on 1 April 1983, 1 July 1983 and 1 January 1984.
—It is a very good policy.

—I am glad to hear the endorsement of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the leadership aspirant of the Liberal Party. The IPP policy results in Australian crude oil being priced at the cost of replacing it with imported crude oil of a similar quality. Relevant factors used in its determination include the cost of importing Arab light purchased at the official government selling price, transport costs, the United States dollar-Australian dollar exchange rate, and an allowance for differences in the quality between the marker and indigenous crudes. As Australia is expected to be a net importer of petroleum over the long term, the principle of pricing Australian crude at its replacement cost provides a sound and stable basis for pricing indigenous crudes. It has also provided a healthy environment for petroleum exploration and development in Australia. The Government will of course continue to monitor the situation closely and will keep all options under review. Account will be taken of movements in both overseas crude oil prices and the Australian dollar exchange rate when the Government comes to consider the price to apply after the next adjustment date, which will be 1 May 1985.

—I refer the Attorney-General to the New South Wales Premier's statement that it was possible that the New South Wales tapes extended back to 1967, and to the Attorney-General's own statement that they extend to 1984, covering a much wider period. Now that the Attorney-General has agreed that it is likely indemnities will be granted to some New South Wales police, will he tell the House what investigations he has made to satisfy himself that Mr Justice Stewart's terms of reference regarding the tapes and the powers available to him are sufficient to investigate all aspects of the tapes, and in particular that they are sufficient to explore effectively all of the aspects of organised crime that they disclose? Given that Mr Justice Stewart had limited terms of reference, are the terms of reference wide enough to pursue all those matters, including crimes which fall outside the authority of the National Crime Authority?

—The question is very relevant because, as the honourable member would know, the terms of reference were given in 1981, and they limit it purely to what is called activities related to Terrence John Clark and the Mr Asia syndicate. I think they are not sufficient; I think they have to be widened. The question then is getting the New South Wales Government also to give powers so that he has the powers of a royal commissioner, which he now has, which will give some advantage to get evidence from New South Wales. These are matters I am in the process of discussing. I welcome the honourable member's co-operation because it will require new letters patent. It will also require perhaps further amendment of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. All those matters, I assure the House, will be very much up front. In other words, what we have been talking about is not really the issue that faces us at present. We want to have as much information as we can get available to Mr Justice Stewart, and he will need information from New South Wales. I am assured that that Government will co-operate in the fullest possible manner.

—I ask the Treasurer: What evidence is there of the accuracy of the statement by the Leader of the Opposition approximately a month ago that retail sales were barely keeping ahead of inflation and that the retail sales figures must be extremely worrying for both retailers and the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to report again that the retail sales figures out today completely refute the claims of the Leader of the Opposition which for months have been absurd in respect of almost any economic comment but particularly comment in respect of retail sales. Today's figures indicate that retail sales rose by 2 1/2 per cent in January. This is the fifth consecutive monthly increase. It means that retail sales are now nearly 10 per cent higher than they were in January 1984.

ANSWER.PARA: An interesting thing is that the increase is not in a narrow area; it is across the board. The big rises in retail sales have been in a range of areas. Sales in department stores are up by 28 per cent on January 1984 figures; grocers' sales are up by 13.5 per cent, hotels' sales are up by 12.3 per cent, clothing stores' sales are up by 14.5 per cent, newsagents' sales are up by 18.6 per cent. So what we are seeing is a very broad movement across the board in consumption and retail sales.

I do not want to dwell upon just one month's figures because we all know that one month's figures can be misleading. To get a more accurate picture, if we look at them on a quarterly basis we find that in the three months to January retail sales grew at a rate of 8.1 per cent higher than they did in the three months to January 1984. In other words, we are experiencing a real increase in retail sales of about 3 per cent, which, of course, is very high.

That increase nails the Leader of the Opposition's mealy-mouthed statements in which he has tried to talk down the economy, which he and his Deputy have been trying to do for months, in respect of retail sales. It is further evidence of support for the prediction I made in the election campaign about consumption exceeding the Budget forecasts. That is supported also by the number of car registrations, which are running at their highest level since 1975.

In terms of further positive pointers to the state of the economy, we see that the stock market yesterday rose to a record 821.2 points, which again indicates the general confidence of investors in the economy. In terms of the survey of the Associated Chambers of Manufactures of Australia, we see there recorded continuing growth for industry, and job vacancies in the three months to February have risen.

Other very hard data on the state of the economy is to be found in the employment figures released a couple of weeks ago, which showed an increase of 45,000 in the number of people employed for the month of February, with 360,000 jobs being created since April 1983. Some 110,000 were created this financial year. We are well on the way to the Budget target of 150,000 for this financial year. Unemployment has therefore declined from 10.4 per cent to 8.3 per cent. That is a dramatic decline from the very high levels of unemployment experienced under our predecessor.

In respect of investment, may I also say that the Australian Statistician's survey records sharp increases in the attitude of business to investment expectations for the coming year. There have been sharp increases in investment for the December quarter. I also indicate again my confidence that the Budget forecasts of an increase in investment of 5 per cent will be either met or exceeded. With that, inflation has come down sharply to 5.1 per cent, from the 1.4 per cent increase we saw in December.

What is happening in the economy is that the fundamentals are coming right, as they have under this Government's policies for two years. Real unit labour costs have returned to the levels of the late 1960s and early 1970s. Industrial disputation is at its lowest since the late 1960s. The profit share of gross domestic profit has been restored from 11.9 per cent in the first half of 1982-83 to 15.3 per cent in 1983-84.

What we are seeing are the clearest signs of the broadening and strengthening of the recovery of the Australian economy. It means that the Budget estimates are on track. This is totally different from the attacks made by the Opposition, which seeks to focus on one statistic here and one statistic there, leaving out of its gaze the general improvement in the economy, the strengthening of the fundamentals, the restoration of the right factor shares in the economy and our dealing with the insidious problem of inflation.

What we will always hear from the Opposition is a series of remarks about a particular month's statistic or some other obscure point but it fails to recognise the general improvement which is taking place. The Opposition is not kidding people in the business community, who for the first time in years not only can see light at the end of the tunnel but also are emerging from the tunnel into days when they can run a business with a decent level of profitability and when there are decent levels of consumption in the economy. The Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy are gravely mistaken if they think they can keep up this barrage of misinformation and abuse of the Government's economic performance when these records are nailing them for what they are-economic frauds, as they have always been.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General and refers to his previous answer to the honourable member for Menzies. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. Is it a fact that the Department of Housing and Construction has rejected unsatisfactory material for works at the Brisbane Airport at a cost of $750,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is a fact. The Department of Housing and Construction entered into four contracts with Blue Rock Quarries for the supply of crushed rock for the Brisbane Airport. It accepted the lowest tender. I understand that this all occurred during February 1983. There was some concern at the ability of the supplier to perform, but the contracts were let on the basis that the specifications would allow the rejection of any unsatisfactory material. However, by May 1983 it was apparent that a problem existed and the Department of Housing and Construction commenced rejection of material from Blue Rock Quarries which was intended for use in the new international Brisbane Airport car park. Blue Rock Quarries then commenced legal proceedings against the Department. Subsequently the Supreme Court found that, on the basis of the wording of the specification, the Department was not entitled to reject. At that point the Department accepted and paid for materials under that contract as decided by the court and used them in the non-critical areas of the car park. Subsequently the Department appealed and lost, again on the wording of the February 1983 specifications.

ANSWER.PARA: We now reach the critical point of the story. The Department then did not accept further samples of materials for the more critical areas of the access roads, taxiways and runways of the new airport. The Department said that the material contained weathered material, was not hard and durable and ought not to be used in international airport construction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Full stop.

—It is all right for members of the Opposition to talk. Surely by now they have woken up to the fact that there is some significance in the date February 1983. At any rate, in 1984 obviously a tough position had to be taken and the contracts were subsequently cancelled. Blue Rock Quarries then instituted legal action against the Department of Housing and Construction, claiming $1.3m worth of damages. In November 1984, on the advice of new counsel, the Department settled out of court for three-quarters of a million dollars.
—How does he go in Cabinet, Bob?
—Order! I suggest that if honourable members cease interjecting the Minister will be able to complete his answer. I call the Minister.

—Obviously I was concerned at the payout of $750,000 by the Department on the February 1983 contracts. I was concerned that the original February 1983 specifications were totally inadequate and that it had cost the Commonwealth $750,000.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. There are Standing Orders within this place that relate to the nature of matters that should normally be made by way of statement and not by way of response to a question. This answer is quite extreme in its length and I suggest that the Minister has now extended the normal licence that even you extend to him in the bounds of Question Time.

—I am as well aware of the Standing Orders as the Leader of the National Party of Australia is. The Standing Orders, so far as questions and answers are concerned, have been observed in this case. However, I do ask the Minister to round off his answer.
—The honourable member for Griffith asked a question which is quite important to the Brisbane area.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the Minister not aggravate the situation and complete his answer.

—I then ordered an independent inquiry which was conducted by Professor L. K. Stevens, the Dean of the Faculty of Engineering at the University of Melbourne. Later today, after Question Time, I intend to table his report. Briefly, the professor found that the Department had acted properly in rejecting the material and in cancelling the contracts and he rejected any suggestion that there had been any deviousness on the part of the Commonwealth. He found further that the specifications relied upon were inadequate for their purpose. On reading Professor Stevens's findings, I instructed the Department to review its specifications to ensure that in future they will be both technically and legally adequate. Secondly-
—Order! I suggest that the Minister round off his answer. He has already referred to the tabling of a paper.

—I have instructed the Department to review, very likely through the engagement of an independent outside consultancy, the tendering process and the contract administrative processes of the Department and, finally, to advise me upon the feasibility of setting up a legal branch within the Department of Housing and Construction.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The Minister has about eight sheets of paper there. Does he intend to read them all?
—Order! There is no point of order. I think the Minister has indicated that he has completed his answer.

—Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that the community employment program, in its first year report, stated that its 'fundamental objective is to assist the most disadvantaged groups of unemployed in obtaining permanent employment in the general labour market' and indicated a total commitment of $730m-most of it Federal funds-creating 52,000 jobs, often for radical Left groups?
—If you have a million dollars everyone is on the Left.

—I am from the private sector; I do not mind a bit of competition. Is the Minister further aware that no system has yet been established to measure how many people from those make-believe jobs have now been employed in the general labour market? Will the Minister say whether this extraordinary situation arises because of his Department's inefficiency or is it a deliberate attempt to inflate artificially the jobs-created numbers? Will the Minister undertake to remedy this situation immediately so that he can assure us that he is not wasting three-quarters of a billion dollars of taxpayers' money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's disparaging remarks about the community employment program seem to indicate a view on his part that job creation schemes are not worth spending money on. In that case he might ask why the previous Government introduced the wage pause program as a job creation scheme, on which the CEP is an improvement but, nevertheless, of the same ilk, that is, a government job creation scheme. The purpose of the job creation scheme we are operating as the CEP is designed most definitely to provide opportunities to people who would not have job opportunities from normal economic recovery. They are the most disadvantaged people in the work force. This applies particularly to the long term unemployed.

ANSWER.PARA: The simple facts of life, which the honourable member should understand, are that these people will not be able to get jobs quickly because they are disadvantaged in the sense of their low self-esteem and their confidence in getting a job. Also, employers tend to view a person who has been unemployed for a long time as not such a good employment prospect. The CEP gives these people a chance to show that they can hold down a job, that they can get a good reference, and therefore can go to an employer with much better employment prospects than would otherwise have been the case.

Preliminary research that has been carried out shows that under the wage pause program about half of the participants went on to get permanent full time jobs, and that is encouraging. We are having further work done on that through the Bureau of Labour Market Research. Work is also being done on the community employment program. It is a total and absolute nonsense to say, as I thought I heard the honourable member say, that all this money has been spent on left wing groups. I do not know where he got that delusion from. It is overwhelmingly the case, of course, that the funds have been spent through State governments and local government, and some funds have been spent through the Federal Government. About 20 per cent of the funds have been spent through community groups, which comprise all sorts of groups, some of which might be seen by the honourable member as being a little on the left of centre. However, those groups essentially cover the spectrum which represents the community. There certainly cannot be said to be any political bias to the Left in terms of the funding of sponsors for CEP undertakings-far from it.

I also inform the honourable member that the latest figures available to me show that so far under the CEP we have created 67,000 jobs. Of course, many of those have gone through to completion. The number of persons placed has been 56,000. So far $709m in CEP funds has been committed. Those expenditures and commitments are certainly giving a chance to people who would not otherwise have a chance of getting a job. It is a very worth while program and one which, rather than disparaging, the honourable member for Deakin would do well to support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Transport been drawn to media reports on the New South Wales Government's decision to lower the driving age? How does this relate to the Federal Government's graduated licensing concept proposed to the States last year? What has been the response in other States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his very important question. The death of young people on our roads is an extremely serious social issue. When we recognise that each year some 1,000 young Australians between the ages of 17 and 25 years are killed and 11,000 are seriously injured and, when we look at those figures in the context of the proportion that young people comprise of the total population, we find that whilst males between 17 and 25 years of age represent about 8 per cent of the population, they constitute 30 per cent of road deaths.

ANSWER.PARA: If we look further at the presence of alcohol in the bodies of those young people who died, we find that, for all drivers involved in fatal crashes with a positive blood alcohol concentration, 49 per cent-almost 50 per cent-were young people, males between 17 and 25 years of age. This Government and, increasingly, State governments have refused to stand by and not take direct and positive action to overcome that problem.

Each day road deaths in this country cost more than $8m. Every two and a half hours on average somebody is killed on our roads and something like 30,000 people are injured a year. The complacency of our general population about that is something which I know most honourable members in this chamber cannot understand. All governments are now trying to change that complacency.

I am most heartened by the decision of the New South Wales Government yesterday. I have been advocating, on behalf of our Government, for some time that we ought to be moving towards the introduction of a staged learner driving process for young people. The age at which a person begins to drive is not nearly as important as the quality and the length of the learning experience. The New South Wales decision to reduce the age at which a person can begin to learn to drive from 17 years to 16 years is a very important and a very welcome step. That first step in a way implements the graduated driver licensing concept that this Government has been promoting. It extends the length of the learning period.

The change the New South Wales Government has made to cease withdrawing licences and penalising people with points on their licences for relatively minor offences removes the punitive approach to young people. Rather, it gives them the opportunity to learn to drive at an earlier age and not being heavy-handed with the penalties encourages them to drive in a better fashion. At the same time, the implementation of 0.02 blood alcohol limit for all young drivers and P-plate holders again is a step in the right direction. It is effectively a zero blood alcohol content. This separates the learning to drink and the learning to drive processes, that fatal combination in young people, whose bodies are not seasoned to the intake of alcohol, at the same time as beginning to learn to drive. It breaks that link, and that again is a very welcome step forward for New South Wales and all of Australia.

If we look around Australia now we find that the South Australian Government is in the process of putting together a pilot program for graduated driver licensing, New South Wales has lowered its driving age and all States now have a zero BAC for young drivers. Both the Tasmanian and Victorian governments are looking critically at the possibility of similar programs to those in South Australia and New South Wales.

In conclusion, I am pleased that the leadership that this Government has been able to give in this area has acted as a catalyst for the State governments around Australia. That improvement in attitude of State governments, with a much greater effort being directed to saving lives and reducing casualities on roads, has also been very ably and appreciably assisted by the media. It is a public education process. In those States and regions where the media have played a more direct and effective role, the reduction in casualties has been greater. We welcome their participation and I hope that, as governments collectively, we can continue on this path.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the matter I raised during the adjournment debate last Thursday. Can the Minister comment on the operations of the Illawarra Retirement Trust in respect of, firstly, the campaign against tenants of the villages at Woonona and Narooma to collect maintenance fees retrospectively, thus causing great personal suffering and financial hardship; and, secondly, the practice of that organisation in charging all residents of the Illawarra Retirement Trust the total amount of the supplementary pensioner allowance as part of the residents' fees, even though all residents do not receive the allowance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I did hear something of his speech the other night. I was rather surprised to see that that well-known newspaper, the Illawarra Mercury, had maligned the honourable member for raising some questions within this House about the administration of the Illawarra Retirement Trust. I can say to the House that the Department of Community Services is aware of the current situation regarding the fees charged to the hostel residents at Daisy Street and the Woonona village lodges in that area. The Department has some control over the level of fees charged under the terms and conditions outlined in the personal care and hostel care subsidies agreement, which all organisations in receipt of these subsidies are required to sign.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the essence of the disagreement which was referred to by the honourable member the other night and which is referred to in his question today really arises from two classes of residents present within that hostel. There is an earlier group of residents who have been in the hostel for a long time and who were, at one stage, given an oral guarantee that their rents would not be raised in real terms. More recently some practices have been adopted in relation to newer residents which effectively mean that the fees charged for more recent residents and, ultimately, for all residents are related to 85 per cent of the current pension and to the payment of supplementary allowances.

I have to say to the honourable member that, having looked at the situation, the Department of Social Security sees no particular grounds for intervening as the current level of rents being charged are not out of line with the general practice which, with respect to hostel accommodation, is increasingly to link fees very much to the question of pensions. But I can understand his concern that there are people who are not receiving supplementary allowances and whose incomes are not related to that formula, who have been there for a long time and who are paying very much higher rents than they would normally be expected to pay. It is not an area in which the Government can intervene, nor do I think the honourable member ought to be maligned for raising what I think is a very responsible concern and one that my Department will continue to monitor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Where a member of the Australian judiciary, sitting as a Federal royal commissioner, has been granted the right to sit and take evidence in the country of a friendly government, does he believe it proper and appropriate for that member of the judiciary to make comment before he hands down his report prior to and subsequent to his taking that evidence? In particular, does he endorse the remarks of Mr Justice McClelland about the British Prime Minister and the policies of the British Government?

—I doubt whether anyone in my Party or outside it would ever pretend to adopt the very onerous role of being the keeper of our friend, now Mr Justice McClelland. He is a free spirit. He is one who has been endowed with a very considerable degree of eloquence which, I believe, has given great joy and comfort to many people over many years. I believe he has conducted himself, in respect of the judicial obligations he has, with distinction. If he has felt, in the atmosphere he finds himself in over there, that there is a need to make certain other observations beyond that role, I think those of us who know him well will understand that. I do not believe anything he has said causes any discomfort to the Government or, importantly, to the people of Australia. Finally I say that those on the other side who may have been the recipients of some of his observations I think have sufficient capacity to understand and, indeed, perhaps even appreciate them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ARTIFICIAL CIGARETTE PACKETS IN EASTER EGGS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Attorney-General been drawn to an article today in the Canberra Times in which one of my constituents reported purchasing a children's novelty Easter egg pack which was found to contain an artificial miniature cigarette packet that could be worn as a pendant? Can he inform the House about progress towards a national consumer product safety commission? Would such an article as this Easter egg pack come under the jurisdiction of such a commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for the question. I am advised that the product has the head of a chicken or a rabbit and contains small chocolate Easter eggs which are visible, but hidden below is a yellow plastic miniature cigarette packet. There is legitimate concern from the point of view of consumers that some products are hazardous. This is being investigated and I am advised that the artificial article in the Easter egg pack is not a hazardous product, but there is a moral question involved, which is the promotion of cigarettes for children. I pay tribute to the company concerned, Sweetoys, which voluntarily withdrew the product as soon as it was made aware of its contents.

ANSWER.PARA: On the more important question of national jurisdiction in respect of product safety, yes, it is important that we do have a national standard. At present there are a number of standards which relate to what are called hazardous products. In some areas States are banning the products and in other areas they are not. There is great concern in consumer associations that there ought to be some uniformity. I am very anxious to achieve that; and, on that basis, we are seeking discussion as to what might be a uniform standard. The Office of Consumer Affairs is in the process of providing options which would enable a Federal government to play a role in product safety. I hope that this will be completed this year. In other words, what we want to do is to ban products that are unsafe, but we need to have some minimum standard. Responsibility at present is a bit diverse. I look forward to the co-operation of the respective State Ministers so that we can get some uniformity in establishing a national consumer product safety commission.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
National Flag
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Carlton and Mr Drummond.

1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult and any increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) The imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many person willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) Those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any category of students.
2. any form of Stamp Duty or similar system of the ''user pays'' principle in education not be introduced.
3. emphasis should be on increasing access to education by, among other things, increasing student financial asistance.
4. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
5. the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs immediately clarify the government's attitude to the reintroduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hurford and Mr Kerin.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That the Assets Test will mean the sale of homes, of cars, and treasured possessions which have been accumulated over many years of hard work and saving;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of old people is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's deception of the Australian dairy industry and the people of Victoria.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In proposing this matter of public importance let me say that the Hawke Labor Government will come to regret having treated the Australian dairy farmers in such a shabby fashion. It says a lot about the deceitful way in which the Government is prepared to treat the problems of people. The people of Victoria and the Australian dairy industry have been subjected to one of the most cynical, despicable, deceitful ploys that I can ever recall. The sudden reversal of the Cain Labor Government's opposition to the national self-help dairy marketing plan two days before polling day in Victoria has proved to be no more than a giant political stunt aimed at rescuing Labor in Victoria from imminent electoral defeat.

SPEECH.PARA: The apparent breakthrough in the dairy plan talks and the promise of a milk inquiry successfully defused industry anger, eased tensions in Victoria, and resulted in the lifting of milk blockades on election eve. People were led to believe that the vital initiatives needed to lift the Victorian dairy industry out of its crisis were in sight. Premier Cain acted out his part in the political conspiracy, taking the Damascus road to Canberra as the saviour of the Victorian farmers. The Primary Industry Minister (Mr Kerin) acted out his role as the passive but reluctant yielder. This stunt was convincing enough at the time for the Premier of Victoria to grab a few hundred votes-the few hundred votes he needed in a handful of lower House seats for him to cling to power. I draw the attention of honourable members to headlines in the Press:
Cain wins new dairy deal.
Headlines such as these were seen in the media just a day or two before polling day. Other headlines read:
Cain saves the dairying industry.
Milk row over, say rebels.

What cheap propaganda. What low-down cunning. Just how low can the Australian Labor Party get in trying to grab a few votes to deceive the Australian farmers, to treat them as hill-billies, hicks, idiots and fools. Friday's announcement that the national dairy plan has now been tossed aside means that Labor simply cannot be trusted. The Hawke and Cain Labor governments were co-conspirators in an exercise of political deceit. As the Minister is on this side of the House I will hand those newspaper articles to him. Let us see how his conscience likes that. What I cannot understand is why the Minister for Primary Industry was a willing participant in this con trick. It seems out of character for the Minister. He has lowered himself in dignity and I am sure he has destroyed a lot of the respect he had gathered over the years in his service in one field or another.

The Minister watched for two years as the dairy industry negotiated its own self-help marketing plan, first between industry bodies and then between State governments. Now he claims that the agreement reached between the States two days before the Victorian election suddenly made the plan internally inconsistent-and they are his words. Apparently the Minister did not notice that the very minor modifications from that meeting created a major problem. It did not dawn on the Minister until after the Victorian election was over, or if it did he chose not to come clean. The industry was left with an impression that this long-awaited breakthrough had a chance of succeeding.

Although a sufficiently bright picture was painted for the milk blockades to be lifted, there was still good reason for a degree of scepticism within the industry. The obstructionist attitude of the Minister for Primary Industry was of on-going concern to the various farmer organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as it was with sugar.

—Absolutely. The honourable member has hit the cube on the head. Earlier in the year the Minister claimed that the proposal for milk entitlements was dead. When the anxiety of some farmers reached the point of forcing them into militant action, he turned around and made totally false accusations that the milk blockades had been set up by the Liberal and National parties. What a load of rubbish. The Liberal and National parties in Victoria had nothing whatsoever to do with the action that was being taken by those people who were concerned enough to try to give physical expression to their depths of anxiety and concern, living as they are in almost abject poverty.
—Oh!

—The honourable member for McMillan laughs. He does not understand; he does not want to understand, and that is the whole trouble with the Labor Government. Labor members laugh at the problems of farmers whenever they get an opportunity; they are always laughing at the problems of the farming community. On 21 February the Minister announced a meeting of officials of three Labor States on the milk issue, but he later agreed reluctantly that all States should attend. Shortly after, he announced that they would not be allowed to discuss the national marketing plan. Later he conceded that the plan should be discussed. In view of the Minister's record of antagonism towards the industry's plan, I sought clarification from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the eve of the Victorian election that the unanimous support of the industry and all States would be honoured by the Commonwealth Government. The telex read:

SPEECH.PARA: Strongly urge immediate public statement from you endorsing unanimous decision of all States to support key elements of Australian Dairy Industry Conference marketing plan. Electors of Victoria must be left in no doubt over Commonwealth support for this plan. The exhaustive negotiations by industry organisations and State governments must be endorsed by your Government.

There was no attempt by either the Prime Minister or the Minister for Primary Industry to issue any public statement clarifying the Government's position on such an important matter, beyond a statement that the agreed plan would be taken to Cabinet. The people of Victoria were deceived by a shoddy, shabby trick. The Hawke and Cain Labor governments engaged in a deliberate exercise to deceive the Victorian people, and the Cain Labor Government has been returned to office on false premises.

The imposition of the new marketing rules announced on Friday will only plunge the industry deeper into crisis. Well over half the farmers could go to the wall; 20,000 jobs will be lost. Who could trust Labor after this stunt? There is general agreement that production of 5.9 billion litres of milk in 1983-84 and 1984-85 is too high, against the background of world oversupply. The Australian Dairy Industry Conference's modified plan sought a lowering of this figure to 5.3 billion litres, an initial step to reduce production. But the new plan will induce a savage cutback to around 4.6 billion litres. It has attracted industry condemnation. United Dairy Farmers of Victoria President, Mr Bill Pyle, said it was an overreaction to surplus production and would lead to a milk war and produce a shortage of milk by 1988. The ADIC Chairman, Mr John Bennett, has described the plan as 'insidious', predicting that it would cost the industry between $50m and $150m a year. Every State Minister within the Commonwealth has condemned the action taken by the Hawke Labor Government. That includes Ministers in Labor governments as well.

The plan fails to recognise that there are world market opportunities that should not be given away to the European Economic Community or to New Zealand. Under the ADIC plan, Australia would have had a buffer of some one billion litres a year for the export market. The Minister's plan will cut dairy exports to insignificance. His plan fails to take account of the efforts by the EEC to cut its overproduction. In the three years to 1979-80, the EEC was producing three times its domestic requirements of whole milk powder, 63 per cent more than its demand for concentrated milk, and was also producing surpluses of butter, skim milk powder and cheese. I have been personally assured by the French Minister for Agriculture, Mr Rocard-I am sure the Minister is aware of this-that the dairy surpluses are being reduced. As the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, Mr Malcolm Vawser, made clear at the recent National Agricultural Outlook Conference:
Given the economics of our production, Australia will be in a position to compete effectively in the export market when the EEC and USA structural surplus problems are eventually rationalised.

By decimating our export sector, the Minister is also abandoning hope that the ailing International Dairy Agreement can be renegotiated. Australian dairy exports earned $350m in the last financial year. This vital export income will be slashed if the Minister's plan remains unaltered. The Australian dairy problem is not a result of the domestic policies of the Commonwealth Government or the 1977 unproclaimed legislation. Contrary to the general perception, the Australian industry is relatively efficient. It has undergone enormous adjustment over the past two decades with dairy farms having reduced in number from 49,000 20 years ago to about 19,700 today.

The industry has improved its productivity and efficiency. In spite of this reconstruction the industry now faces its toughest challenge for reasons beyond its control. The Government has set the stage for a milk marketing war. Worse still, in rejecting the national dairy marketing plan which is supported not only by the farmers but also by all States the Hawke Labor Government has declared war on the dairy farmers and in so doing on the farming community generally. The Minister makes no mention of our reduced export capacity, the social and economic upheaval facing dairy families or the prospect of a milk shortage and artificially high prices a few years down the track. Neither the dairy sector nor Australian consumers will be fooled by such a tactic.

This is not a plan for free enterprise; it is a plan for the destruction of the export capacity of a vital national industry at a time when Australia should be endeavouring to increase its export earnings. This cheap political trick and the prospect of a milk price war has the potential benefit of temporarily reducing inflation at the cost of farmers. Already this tactic has been used by not increasing the price of manufactured milk products. Manufactured milk product prices remained static from 1 December 1982 until this year, but over that period government services, charges, wages and other costs have risen significantly. The excuse used by the Government, that a price rise would encourage overproduction, was answered by the industry's national plan incorporating entitlements which would reflect the true value of marginal production. The Government has chosen another more vicious course. It has embarked on a course which will slash farm returns and force thousands of farmers and their families out of the industry. Let no one claim that milk and dairy product prices are too high in Australia. Australia's prices for butter and cheese, for example, are lower than those of any of the major producers such as Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany, France and Sweden.

In blocking price increases for more than two years the Government has ratted on the dairy farmers of this country. It would never have dared to impose such restrictions on the members of trade unions. Labor still clings to its centralised wage fixation system with full indexation-a most highly protected system for the wage earners of this country. Yet it is prepared to impose another set of circumstances upon the dairy farmers of Australia.

Under the new marketing plan there is no provision for entitlements. Farmer will be pitted against farmer in a savage battle to remain in production. The underwriting of exports will put the workforce of Australia into free competition as well. The underwriting of exports will fall from 95 per cent to 90 per cent using a three year average and export pooling will not apply after 30 June this year. The levy on all milk is to be set at a maximum of 2c a litre. Levies on butter, et cetera, will be phased out within a maximum of six years. The dairy industry's own self-help plan was an attempt-not by the Government, but by the industry-to support its own manufacturing milk prices and to achieve a more gradual rationalisation over a longer period.

The Cain Labor Government, with the co-operation of the Hawke Labor Government, has regained power on false pretences. If either the Federal Government or the Victorian Labor Government thinks that primary producers at large will simply forget this trick, they are deceiving themselves. The Minister can rest assured that farmers have long memories and they will not forget his role in this matter. This action by the Minister will reinforce that suspicion for years to come. The Minister had earned some respect amongst farming communities. He has done it in properly on this dairying issue. It is a cheap, political, low-down, cunning trick against the dairy farmers of Australia and therefore against the farming community generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) deserves 10 out of 10 for acting. Even the dries of the Liberal Party of Australia, including the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), are not completely dry-eyed after that exposition. I am not going to comment particularly on headlines because the results of decisions taken by Governments are far more serious than some newspapers seek to interpret. I am disappointed in the Opposition for raising a matter of public importance that focuses on one State. The big problem for the Australian Government-the national Government-is to try to get in place a national dairy industry policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem that has bothered sequential Australian parliaments and governments-at least back to 1934 when I think the first meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council was held, where I think the second item on the agenda was the failure of the States to agree on dairying-has always been that we have had six separate dairy industries and that each State has acted to preserve its own dairy industry. I freely acknowledge that each dairying State has particular problems to service its own metropolitan markets year round with milk, but at no time due to the powerful and vested interests that have grown up in each State, have the States ever been prepared to look at this industry nationally. I am not going to come in here and say that one State has been particularly persecuted or that one State has made particular gains. I resent the Opposition's attack in terms of divisiveness. Dairy farmers in New South Wales and Queensland refer to Victorians as Mexicans. That is not a very constructive way to go about things. Today we have the Opposition perpetuating the reverse sort of division. The reality is that Victoria is the largest dairying State. It now produces nearly 60 per cent of the milk in Australia.

When the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) was the Minister for Primary Industry in 1977 he tried to get some sort of agreement between the States then. Again, it was Victoria that held out. It has been the Victorian Government which has held out throughout the negotiations and discussions since November 1983 when the most recent final report by the Industries Assistance Commission brought down its recommendations. One of the very big problems that the Australian dairy industry faces overall is the fact that the Victorian Liberal Party, when in government in that State, for so long constantly encouraged dairy production whatever the market reality was. The sad thing today is that Victoria and, to a lesser extent, Tasmania now produce over 90 per cent of the exports in this country. That is why the pressure is falling most heavily on Victoria. It will be so and would have been so if no action had been taken. It would have been so if the Government had moved for total deregulation. Victoria would have borne the pressure of adjustment if the Australian Dairy Industry Conference scheme had been put into place.

It is nothing new for dairy farmers to be dissatisfied, because there are fundamental problems with dairy industries in the developed countries throughout the world. When I was in the United Kingdom recently I ascertained that the dairy farmers in that country were virtually stoning the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food because the European Economic Community tried to introduce some sort of quota system. In the United States of America, which I also visited recently, the same sort of process is under way. There is too much milk and too many dairy products are stockpiled. There is a big problem in this regard throughout the world. Australia does not have the problem those countries have because those countries have subsidised their industries to the hilt and have further engaged in subsidies to get rid of the surpluses. I am afraid that as a reality we have to take into account the fact that we do not have the treasuries of North America and the EC.

I put it to the House that sometimes tough decisions have to be taken. What the Opposition will concentrate on, of course, is opposition to the Government's tough decision. It will not concentrate on the problems of the dairy industry or their solution. There is no sense in the Opposition's taking refuge in the Cain-ADIC scheme, if I can so describe it, because basically it was not a feasible scheme, and I will get to that in a moment. The Cabinet takes decisions. There is no sense in making allegations about lack of consultation. That is really a bit rich when the Australian Agricultural Council met five times, the Cabinet met five times, and either I or my Department had hundreds of meetings with the industry. At those five Agricultural Council meetings the Victorian Government opposed entitlements tooth and nail-if I had time I would read out the minutes from the various meetings-and then suddenly it believes it can turn around on this matter. It did get some agreement, and again if I had time I would get on to the area of agreement and the reason why the Cabinet rejected the proposition as unworkable and infeasible.

Surely by this time the Opposition, with all the experience it has had in government, might have come up with some substantive, constructive policies on this industry. The Liberal Party does not take primary industry or rural policy seriously. I guess basically it has a philosophy, a reaction. I heard a commentator say the other day that the Liberal Party had not changed its philosophies since 1908. The Liberal Party is not serious about rural policy in this House, but it certainly is in the Victorian and Tasmanian parliaments. The National Party, of course, is a user party. I guess I could recite the policy on dairying that the coalition agreed to at the time of the last election. God knows when the Liberal Party will take some interest in rural policy. We might get a bit more sense from the coalition then. This is the policy from the rural specialists:

the Liberal/National parties are determined to improve the efficiency and economic viability of the Australian dairy industry. This will be achieved by improving industry accountability and implementing realistic policies on domestic pricing, imports, exports, underwriting and stabilisation. Marketing research and product promotion will be increased.

That is lovely motherhood stuff, but it does not really bear down on the problems of the amount of production. It does not really bear down on the inherent problems in the structure of the dairy industry. Let us get down to the fine detail:
domestic pricing will be freed up to attract sufficient milk production to meet Australian domestic requirements on a year-round basis;
In the deepest of the deep droughts in this country there has never been any problem, any worry, about the dairy industry's capacity to supply the market. The policy continues:
we will continue the Joint Industry Consultation Group discussions with New Zealand.
That is another nice motherhood one. God knows what the coalition means when it says:
the Liberal/National parties believe the Australian dairy industry should make the best use of economic production and minimum transport costs.
This is the really confusing bit:
Underwriting will be pursued to reflect established production patterns and market prices.

Underwriting is not pursued to reflect that; underwriting is pursued to take account of a sudden drop in the international price. We have to adjust to some market reality. We are an open economy. If we did not do that in other areas we would have many more blacksmiths than people who at present make computer chips. There is not any debate about the need for or the inevitability of adjustment in this industry. There is debate about how we can put in place measures that will facilitate sensible adjustment. TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with order of the day No. 2, namely, the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Government members for coming into the chamber to listen to an interesting debate on extradition law. The Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill 1985 and the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Bill 1985, according to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), are to improve significantly our extradition laws and to facilitate the processing of extradition requests by Australia and requests made of Australia. The way in which it has been put by the Attorney-General-namely, to improve our extradition laws and to facilitate the processing of these extradition requests-is, I must say, something of an exaggeration.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true, of course, that the Bills amend our extradition laws and it is also true that most of the proposed changes are desirable. But they are, in the view of the Opposition, a far cry from the complete overhaul of our extradition laws that is needed. The Attorney-General recently has been giving himself a pat on the back, as if the Government had thrown itself with great enthusiasm and vigour into reforming the extradition laws, and the Government had solved all the problems relating to extradition law. In reality, the Government we submit has done comparatively little in this field and what it has done has been brought about by its being galvanised into action by the embarrassment that it has suffered as a result of the Trimbole matter.

Let me support that proposition by referring to the February 1983 report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the remarks made in that report on our extradition laws. I invite honourable members to see how those remarks made in the Stewart Royal Commission report measure up against the Government's feeble response which is contained in the Bills which are presently before the House. In the Stewart Royal Commission report, the Royal Commissioner made a number of points. At page 669 of the report the Royal Commissioner stated:

It is obviously desirable, in the opinion of the Commission, that the Commonwealth Government should pursue a policy of replacing as soon as possible these old and uncertain treaties with modern treaties entered into by Australia itself with the relevant foreign state and being so far as practicable uniform in content as to the relevant procedures involved in the extradition process to the intent that the same may be simplified and made certain.

In relation to the foreign states to which the Extradition (Foreign States) Act does not yet apply, including the foreign states mentioned earlier with which treaties are currently being negotiated, it is desirable that effective treaties be concluded as soon as possible with such foreign states and that the Act be applied to them.

That is the end of the quotation from the Stewart Royal Commission report, but it will be observed from what I have read out that the view of the Royal Commission was that there was a lot of work ahead for the Government in modernising our extradition arrangements so that fugitives from this country could be returned with more speed than we have seen in the most recent case and that generally the extradition system should be improved.

Madam Deputy Speaker, having in mind what Mr Justice Stewart said, you may well ask: 'How many treaties have in fact been placed? How many treaties have been negotiated? Is there now a uniform treaty; and, if so, where is it and what does it contain? Have our extradition proceedings been simplified and made more certain? How many effective treaties have been negotiated, as Mr Justice Stewart recommended in early 1983, and how many are being negotiated now?' All of these matters are left to our imagination. Insofar as the Government has an obligation-which is an obligation concerned with a great matter of public interest, particularly in the case of the Trimbole matter-one cannot help but come to the conclusion that the Government has failed in its responsibility to explain to the House, the Parliament and the people just what it has done about these observations of Mr Justice Stewart in regard to improving our extradition arrangements. It is not just as if they were remarks made by the Royal Commissioner, because when he came to make his recommendations he made a number of specific recommendations which in his view should be acted upon. Recommendation 55 states:

Consideration should be given to enacting legislation to permit a criminal trial to be held in the absence of an accused when he is a fugitive who cannot be found or extradited or a prisoner serving a lengthy term of imprisonment in another country.
That recommendation is to be found at page 840 of the report. Recommendation 56 states:

The Commonwealth Government should examine whether the 'inherited' treaties listed in Part Five (c) (xvi) of this report should be replaced by treaties entered into by Australia directly with each foreign country so that:
the grounds of extradition may be made more clearly defined;
procedures for extradition may be simplified; and
so far as possible, procedures may be made uniform.
That recommendation is also to be found at page 840 of the report. The Royal Commissioner says in recommendation 57:

The Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department should keep a full record of extraditions sought by or of Australia and, in consultation with the State Attorneys-General, should monitor the effectiveness of Australian law and international treaties concerning extradition and the utility of the procedures relating thereto.

That recommendation is to be found at page 840 of the report. As I have already said, the Government has had this report since it came to office. The report is dated February 1983 and I presume the Government has had it since March 1983. We can well ask: What has it done about those recommendations? Has it considered any of those recommendations? What does it say about trial in the absence of the accused? I hasten to add that I am not advocating it, but what I do want to know is whether it is a recommendation made by a royal commissioner about whom the Government scarcely allows a day to go by without lauding him and his great achievements. That is a recommendation Mr Justice Stewart has made. If it is a recommendation that he has made the Parliament is entitled to know the Government's thinking in specific terms, not the wishy-washy promise to consider it which Senator Gareth Evans gave some months ago. We want to know whether the Government has rejected that recommendation. If the Government has rejected it we want to know why. We want to know what the Government says about recommendation 56. Has it done anything at all to examine whether the treaties concerned should be replaced? We would venture to suggest that it is only the Trimbole matter which has galvanised the Government into the modicum of action it has taken so far on extradition treaties. It is fair to say that the Government did nothing at all until the Trimbole matter became a matter of public interest and concern. If I may say so, with as much modesty as I can muster on this matter, it is probable that the Press statements that I and other people have issued on the subject and the Press comment on the subject drew to the attention of the public the fact that our extradition arrangements were far from adequate.

The Government has taken some action. It would be churlish not to concede that the Government has at least done something. We would have thought that a second reading speech on extradition law, especially at this time when the Trimbole matter is an area of such great public interest, would have brought the House up to date on the Government's weighty and sustained deliberations on this matter, if indeed it has been considering them. One is understandably sceptical about the establishment of the task force to modernise our extradition arrangements when one realises that it was of course established, if I recall correctly, only in February this year. Again, that was after the Trimbole matter became a matter of such great public concern. Regrettably, the second reading speech is silent on all of this.

Let us put the matter into perspective by saying that although the amendments proposed in the Bills before the House are, of course, for the most part desirable-one cannot argue against that-they are, in comparison with the real overhaul of our extradition treaties which is needed, comparatively minor and comparatively trifling. Just to illustrate this point, we find, for instance, that one of the amendments proposed by the Bills contains the proposition that a fugitive who waives the full extradition process can be returned voluntarily to the country that wants him back to stand trial. If the Government believes that that momentous change in the law is desirable, we have no objection to it. However, we ask the question: Of what practical use is it? It amounts to saying that if Mr Trimbole, for instance, had agreed to come back to Australia voluntarily we would have been able to receive him. One could not really say that that was all that remarkable an achievement. Nevertheless if the Government takes the view that this amendment to the law is needed we certainly will not object to it. However, we say that it falls short of the needed strengthening and modernisation of our extradition laws.

The second change to which I wish to refer is that an appeal will be allowed by a country requesting a fugitive to be returned if the magistrate hearing the case rejects the extradition request. In our view, that is a reasonable amendment and the Opposition will support it. If the fugitive himself may appeal against an order extraditing him, as he may, the country requesting the fugitive to be returned should have the right to appeal against an order refusing extradition.

The next amendment is of more substance. This amendment will include taxation offences, customs offences, foreign exchange control offences and other revenue matters amongst the list of extraditable offences. The Opposition will support that amendment because modern crime, especially modern organised crime, is just as likely to be involved in revenue crimes as it is to be involved in the more traditional crimes. It is appropriate that people who commit revenue crimes be just as subject to extradition arrangements as those who are involved in more traditional crimes. However, it seems to our mind-we have not had a great deal of time to examine this legislation in detail-that in amending the nature of extraditable crimes the Government is making a further substantial change which is not mentioned in the second reading speech.

The amendment makes an offence an extradition crime if the maximum penalty is death or imprisonment for not less than 12 months. There may be some good reason for this being done, but the second reading speech does not make it clear why this change is being made. Unless I have overlooked something, which I may well have done, neither does the explanatory memorandum make it clear why this change is being implemented. I hasten to say that there may well be a very good reason for this change. We certainly would not stand in the Government's way in making this change if there were a good reason for it. But as things stand at the moment the Opposition is not convinced that one can say in any universal sense that crimes for which the punishment is imprisonment for less than 12 months should not be extraditable crimes. The Opposition invites the Attorney-General to explain why this change is desirable and, if there is a persuasive reason for it, we would support it actively. But at present there is no reason which has been advanced to us of which I am aware as to why offences punishable by imprisonment for less than 12 months should not be extraditable crimes.

The next amendment makes it clear by codification that an extradited person may not be tried in the country that requests his extradition for offences other than those in respect of which his extradition has been granted, or at least not until he has been granted an opportunity of leaving that country, whether it be Australia or another country. The Opposition supports that change to the law on the ground that, when one comes to focus one's mind on the issue, it is on the surface at least unfair that an individual subjected to extradition on one offence should suddenly find himself faced with criminal charges relating to an entirely different offence.

A further amendment changes the law to provide that a decision to refuse extradition because the offence is of a political character may be taken only by the Attorney-General and not by the magistrate. We find this amendment unacceptable, especially when we look at the reason advanced for it in the second reading speech. The reason advanced for it in that speech was that 'decisions of the courts in this area have not been very helpful'. Governments often find decisions of the courts not very helpful on particular matters, but in dealing with whether a person should not be extradited because he is to stand trial in some fascist state or some extreme socialist state or dictatorial state because the offence is of a political character-and countries of that sort have many offences of a political character, or dress them up as being legitimate offences, whereas in reality there is a political motive behind them-the Opposition's view is that in those circumstances that sort of matter should not be left solely to the discretion of the Attorney-General. It smacks of quite unnecessary restriction on the citizen's rights because the Executive is not getting the sorts of decisions from the courts that it wants. This is the worst possible reason for changing the law and the Opposition will not accept a change in the law based on that reason.

Furthermore, in relation to that amendment I point out that the Bill does not provide a right of appeal to challenge the Attorney-General's determination of what is and what is not a political offence. That is an additional reason for not accepting this proposed change in the law. In substance, the Opposition believes that the matter should be left to the courts and that there should be a right of appeal, and that is substantially where the matter stands at the moment.

As I have already pointed out, the Opposition has not had a great deal of time to examine this matter in detail, but we are anxious to assist the Government with its legislative program. Because we have not had a great deal of time to examine this matter, the Opposition has instituted a division of labour. My colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) will be proposing an amendment to expand further on our position. He will be proposing that amendment in Committee and I adopt what he is about to say on that matter. The substance of the Opposition's argument is that we do not believe it appropriate for this sort of determination of what is and what is not a political offence to be left to the discretion or decision of the Attorney-General. I am not referring to the current Attorney-General, who I am sure would make the right decision on these matters, but one has to think of future Attorneys-General, as on occasions we think of past Attorneys-General.

An Attorney-General is a politician, although he is separate from all other ministries, including the Prime Minister, and he has a different role from all other Ministers. Nevertheless, he is a political figure, an elected figure, a member of a government. He has views on the political regimes that operate in other countries, and may take a completely different view from the community in general, or from the Opposition, or from the parties involved in extradition proceedings as to what is or what is not a political offence. He might say 'We will let that person be extradited to go back to Libya, Afghanistan or the Soviet Union' or wherever it might be. It might be said 'This person is not in any danger of being subjected to trial for a political offence', whereas a magistrate, a court, or a large section of the community may well say that it is unfair to throw such a person to the wolves in the Soviet Union, Libya or wherever it might be. We believe that the proper solution is to have some independent judgment made on the matter with a right of appeal, and that means going to the courts. My colleague the honourable member for North Sydney will amplify that point and will put what the Opposition believes is a sensible amendment that we urge the Government to accept. If the Government accepts our amendment, we believe it will achieve part of what it wants; yet this will give it an opportunity to concede what we maintain is the merit of our point of view.

The other amendments to the Bill will be accepted by the Opposition. It is pointless my going on simply to occupy time when I can say concisely that we do not oppose other amendments contained in the Bill, although individual honourable members may make their contributions to the debate. I conclude by returning briefly to the point I made at the outset. Despite the Government's self-congratulations on reforms in the extradition field, the Opposition believes, as was emphasised in the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, that the Government has a lot to do ahead of it to modernise our extradition laws and that it should proceed. I assure the Attorney-General and the Government that when proposals are put up for amendment of our extradition laws to modernise, strengthen and bring them into the modern world-the unfortunate modern world of crime and international crime-the Government will have the Opposition's support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most Aust- ralians were quite horrified when Robert Trimbole walked out of the court in Ireland, apparently a free man. This brought home to the Australian public the importance and significance of extradition treaties. I was rather surprised that the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), a former Acting Attorney-General in the Liberal-National Party Government, had the hide to criticise the present Government for doing nothing about extradition.
