SPEECH.PARA: To return to the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill, our nation has over a million visitors a year, and some 100,000 people enter the country every year to live permanently in Australia. We have large numbers of New Zealand residents who move freely from their country to Australia. So it is important that the laws relating to extradition be reviewed. I commend the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for bringing this legislation forward. I point out that the last matter relating to extradition that I could find in the Federal Law Reports was a case involving a New Zealander who came here in 1979. A few years later the New Zealand law officers issued a summons for the arrest of this citizen. Eventually, Mr Justice Yeldham determined that while it was difficult for such a person to go back to New Zealand, it was not too severe a penalty to require him to return to face trial on a serious charge.

The whole tradition of extradition law is such that a visitor to a country who is charged as or alleged to be a fugitive should not be taken back to another country to face trial for a political offence. In the original Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act there is a list of offences that can be brought into play in these proceedings. It has been a long tradition since extradition came into force in the last century that political offences be excluded.

The legislation before Parliament today contains some significant amendments. It allows for the voluntary return of an offender. It allows for an appeal by a requesting country. Previously only a fugitive could appeal from a magistrate's decision. There is an executive discretion to refuse extradition. This proposed amendment will extend the Attorney-General's discretion to refuse extradition in any situation where it would be unjust or oppressive to grant it. At present such discretion may be exercised only if an offence is trivial, if an accusation was made mala fide or if there was a lapse of time which would make it unjust or oppressive to grant extradition. In the case of Bryan v. Preston, in the New South Wales Supreme Court, Mr Justice Yeldham held that a lapse of time of three years was not considered too long to be unjust or oppressive. So, presumably there would have to be a very considerable lapse of time in which witnesses may have died or gone missing. In that case a person accused of a serious offence might not obtain justice on being returned to another country for trial.

Another significant amendment in the Bill is that there will henceforth be extradition for fiscal offences. This amendment makes it clear that offences against laws relating to taxation, Customs duties, foreign exchange controls and other revenue matters which hitherto have not been extraditable will be extraditable. This is a significant change, and it is part of the Government's plan to ensure that the extradition laws relate to issues that are relevant to citizens and that people who breach the revenue laws of a nation cannot escape justice by fleeing that country. There is a speciality rule, which has been touched on by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Menzies. Another amendment relates to offences of a political character. The Attorney-General and not a magistrate will make a decision on these matters. This amendment follows the practice of the Executive in the United States of America. I believe it is the role of the Executive to decide who should be deported to another country to face trial. It should not be the role of a magistrate presiding in a Court of Petty Sessions to have to make a decision in proceedings of a very serious nature and to adjudicate on such charges.

Other matters in the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill have been touched on by the previous speaker. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his second reading speech on the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Bill pointed out that the amendments proposed in that Bill were being introduced by the Government to facilitate the fight against major crime, particularly illicit dealing in narcotic drugs. This is part of the Commonwealth's overall plan to combat drug trafficking. It is a matter of concern to all members of this House and to all other Australians that the laws on extradition must not protect people who are criminals, people who flee our country to avoid apprehension or, alternatively, people who have come to our nation to avoid trial in their own countries.

I believe that this legislation is quite straightforward. The honourable member for Menzies touched on the Trimbole case, but of course it had nothing whatsoever to do with this legislation. Trimbole, or 'Aussie Bob' as he was called in Ireland, escaped on a technicality due to a breach of Irish constitutional law and this had nothing to do with the extradition law that had or had not been brought in. He was wrongly apprehended and was wrongly charged by members of the Irish police in their enthusiasm to apprehend him. It was on a constitutional point that Mr Justice Egan in the Irish Supreme Court directed that Trimbole be released. The legislation before the House today is commendable legislation. I recommend it to the House and call for honourable members to reject the amendments that have been circulated in the name of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender).

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to have to start by saying to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), that his hope that the amendments circulated in my name will be rejected will not be realised, as I have been advised by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that he accepts them. The Opposition view, as outlined by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), is that the amendments before the House are useful. They make improvements. SPEECH.PARA: There is no general right of extradition under international law. For those who are students of history or, indeed, of pre-history, it seems that the first extradition treaty was concluded in the year 1280 BC, or thereabouts, between Egypt and a Hittite prince, for the return of criminals. Perhaps the most well known of all extradition treaties was the treaty between Rome and Syria which provided for the surrender of Hannibal. However, the real beginnings of international co-operation in extradition matters began somewhere in the nineteenth or late eighteenth century. There is a need for us to look to extradition measures and to examine the means by which they can become more efficient and more speedy, because it is all too obvious that speed is so often of the essence in extradition cases. The Trimbole case, which unhappily failed from our point of view because an Irish court took the view that the original charge against Trimbole was in effect a trumped up charge and that therefore the whole matter was tainted, serves to emphasise how necessary it is that procedures should be flexible, efficient and quick. The need for reform in this area is summed up in an excellent book by Mr Ivor Stanbrook and his brother, entitled The Law and Practice of Extradition. I refer to page 28 of the introduction, which states:

There is manifestly an urgent need for the reform of the law of extradition in view of its great complexity and present inability to deal with the growing problems of international gangsterism. Comparatively few of the world's states are linked together in formal extradition arrangements; moreover, those arrangements which exist are hedged about with restrictions which owe more to narrow-mined nationalism than to ideals of justice. Exemption clauses arising out of the nationality of the offender and the political character of the offence may be justified where there are deep ideological divisions between states: among democracies greater mutual trust might be expected.

I think that certainly should apply amongst democracies. Unfortunately, there are too few of them. The particular matter that is going to be brought before the House by way of amendment to the Bill relates to the discretion, or the power, to put it more accurately, which was to be taken from the courts and vested in the Attorney-General to determine whether or not an offence for which a person was allegedly sought to be extradited was an offence of a political character. The amendments proposed to the two Bills by the Opposition effectively do this. Firstly, the amendments preserve the position of the courts so that the courts can say: 'No, he should not be extradited because the offence is of a political character'. Secondly, they add an additional safeguard by adding these words to the court's power to deny extradition, namely:
or that the requisition for his surrender has in fact been made with a view to try or punish him for an offence of a political character.

Those words are modelled on words which appear in the United Kingdom Extradition Act of 1870. The need for them these days can be well appreciated. It is easy enough for a foreign power to trump up a charge against one of its citizens and then to move in the courts of this country and say 'We want this man back'-to wherever the country may be-'for the purposes of meeting charges that he drove a car while drunk and while doing so killed somebody'; whereas the truth of the matter is that extradition is sought, not to have the man or woman brought back to meet criminal charges but so that that person can be brought back to meet charges of an essentially political nature, such as crimes against the state, which Soviet Russia has made so infamous. Effectively, therefore, we add that additional safeguard when the matter has been considered by the court. When the matter has been considered by the Attorney-General, his powers are on all fours with the court's so that he can independently come to the view that what is proposed is that a man or woman should be taken out of this country to meet essentially a political charge.

The great benefit of this kind of tandem approach is that on occasions, no doubt, courts can be too strict and perhaps too ill-informed of the outside world in the way in which they go about dealing with a matter. On occasions-not while the present Attorney-General is in the chair, but on future occasions-there may be Attorneys-General, of whatever political persuasion, who because of their own political views would take an unsympathetic and fundamentally wrong view about a person's case when that person said: 'Look, the truth of the matter is that they are seeking to get me not for what I have allegedly done in criminal terms but for my politics'. That provides a nice balance and a nice safeguard so that the Attorney-General has the power and the courts have the power. Of course, there would be no appeal against the Attorney-General's exercise of his powers.

As I have indicated, that is the important matter the Opposition wishes to put before the House. The only other comments I wish to make relate to matters that appear in Mr Justice Stewart's report of February 1983. I appreciate that law reform is difficult, or can be difficult, but we must all appreciate the great urgency of the need to come to grips in all ways with organised crime. It is of no use that we can prove in Australia that a person who has fled the jurisdiction has been guilty of a number of serious crimes if we cannot get him back to try him. It is because of that kind of consideration that the recommendations made by Mr Justice Stewart need to be considered, and should have been considered long before now. The Government-allowing more than two years to pass without coming forward with any answers to the proposals made by Mr Justice Stewart, as outlined by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown)-has moved with all the speed and sense of dedication and purpose of an arthritic tortoise. When the Attorney-General speaks to the House I ask him to advise us when it is that we can expect to have a response on the three recommendations made by Mr Justice Stewart and which were referred to by my friend the honourable member for Menzies. In particular, what about the case where a person is in prison in another country, where evidence is available in Australia of a very compelling nature to the effect that he has been guilty of serious crimes, where the Crown could confidently expect that he would be convicted of those crimes, and yet nothing can be done because, as in the case of Terrence John Clarke, he is serving a sentence of imprisonment of 20 years. It does seem that something is manifestly wrong if we cannot find the means of dealing with that situation because after 20 years the witnesses are dead, those who are still alive have very little real memory of what has taken place, and the acquittal of that individual is virtually assured after he gets out. I agree with the honourable member for Menzies that we do not say on behalf of the Opposition that the proposals canvassed by Mr Justice Stewart should necessarily be agreed to. But they are very serious, they are considered, and they come from a man who has this Government's highest confidence. It is essential that we have a detailed and speedy response to them.

It would be very worth while in response to those kinds of issues raised by Mr Justice Stewart and in response to the general issue of ensuring that the extradition laws of this country are efficient, flexible, work simply, and will assist us in the fight against organised crime if a paper were put before this Parliament similar to the paper put before the United Kingdom Parliament in February 1983 dealing with the whole question of extradition and setting out recommendations as to what should be done with the present law and what changes should be made to the present law. I therefore ask the Attorney-General to give consideration to that course because it would enable the House to have a highly informed debate upon an extremely important subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleagues on this side of the House, I am always surprised at the temerity of those opposite who condemn this Government for lack of speed in anything concerning the position of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). The only contribution the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) has made is not to speak for the 30 minutes allocated to him. He introduced no positive material which would assist this House in determining the merits of the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill now before us. Extradition can be defined as the surrender by one nation to another of an individual accused or convicted of an offence outside his territory and within the jurisdiction of the other, in order that the latter country may try the individual or punish him as the case may be.

SPEECH.PARA: Foreign extradition is solely the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government. The Attorney-General's Department administers the relevant Commonwealth legislation in this area of the law. Until 1966 the basic law of foreign extradition in Australia was the Imperial Extradition Acts of 1870 to 1936. These Acts applied to Australia the extradition treaties negotiated by Great Britain prior to World War II, which were extended to Australia as a British colony and later as a self-governing dominion. The Commonwealth Parliament, under its powers to legislate in respect of external affairs, in 1966 passed legislation, the Extradition (Foreign States) Act, which continued these treaties in force but which also enabled Australia to implement its own extradition treaties. Thus the Extradition (Foreign States) Act applies to any foreign state where immediately before the commencement of the Act an Order-in-Council in force under the extradition Acts applied such Acts to that foreign state and extended them to the Commonwealth of Australia.

The Extradition (Foreign States) Act may also be applied to any foreign state by regulation under the Act when a treaty is entered into between a foreign state and Australia. By contrast, extradition between member states of the Commonwealth has always proceeded on a non-treaty basis, being seen as a system of rendition between different parts of the British Empire owing common allegiance and sharing the same legal concepts and cultural values. Until 1966 the relevant legislation in force was the Imperial Fugitive Offenders Act of 1881.

At a conference of Commonwealth Law Ministers in 1966 it was agreed that this scheme be continued but be revised by the adoption of uniform extradition legislation in each country. Australia implemented this scheme in the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966. It is not every member country of the Commonwealth to which the Act applies but only such countries as are declared-those countries which have implemented the 1966 Commonwealth scheme.

Although treaties formed the original basis for the application of the Extradition (Foreign States) Act, the Act was amended in 1974 to provide for it to be applied by regulation to any country whose law, in the opinion of the Australian Government, permits extradition. This amendment was moved because of the popularity of Brazil-a country which was covered by an imperial treaty-but was terminated by Brazil in 1913, for the likes of Biggs and Barton. Although the Act still continues the policy of reciprocity, a former treaty is no longer a pre-condition of the Commonwealth's power to extradite from a foreign state. The Act now so applies to Brazil.

As the Act now stands, it is necessary for the requesting state to have enacted an offence in corresponding terms to Australian law, be it State or Federal law. Schedule one in both Acts lists those extraditable crimes upon which the Attorney-General can act. There is in form rather than in substance a conflict between non-common law countries, such as Napoleonic code countries, and common law countries. While an act or omission may be, in substance, an offence and be an act or omission punishable in both states-if it is punishable, as such, it would normally permit extradition-that act or omission may not be in a form recognised in Australia and not listed in the present Schedule to the Act. The removal of the list of specified offences recognised the inherent difficulties of comparative law-the difficulty of making comparisons between common law and non-common law countries. Its removal will enhance the existing legislation without removing the vital safeguards of insisting that the act or omission complained of would constitute, if proved, an offence under existing Australian or State law.

A further amendment facilitates arrangements with non-common law countries to allow extradition on the basis of a statement of facts. This removes the necessity of lengthy and difficult hearings in Australia, hearings which are analagous to committal proceedings. This concept is unknown to non-common law countries. As the situation now stands, a fugitive has the advantage of conducting a full preliminary trial in Australia involving the calling of witnesses, the examination and testing of documents and any expert evidence, without any necessity of introducing rebuttal evidence or presenting a defence.

The fugitive rights are not diminished in the proposed amendments. Those amendments do not remove the right of a fugitive to apply for a writ of habeas corpus. The right of the Supreme Court or Federal Court to grant the prerogative writ has not been diminished in any way. The Act vests in the Attorney-General, a magistrate hearing the application and any court to which an application is made for a writ of habeas corpus the power to refuse to surrender a person if satisfied that the offence is trivial, that the accusation was not made in good faith or in the interests of justice, or that the time that has elapsed since the offence was committed is such that having regard to the circumstances of the commission of the offence it would be unjust, oppressive or too severe a punishment to surrender a person. There is also the unfettered power of the Executive to refuse extradition on a ground other than that mentioned.

With respect to the amendment proposed by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), of course, the question of whether a crime is a political matter is not within the province necessarily of the legal system. Magistrates or judges have no special knowledge of international situations which would necessarily enable them to determine in a judicial manner whether the complaint alleged by the requesting state is or is not a political offence. Hence the amendment, while it is non-objectionable, does not take away the fact that ultimately the right to refuse extradition always lies in the Attorney-General. So the Attorney-General ultimately always has the power to refuse on any of those grounds the extradition of any person in this country.

Like honourable members opposite, I am very pleased to see included in the Bill, in conformity with the European Convention on Extradition, those matters of a fiscal or revenue nature. There is no doubt that in this world today large companies and other individuals, be they of the Left persuasion, as is suggested, or of the extreme Right persuasion, as is not suggested, are more than anxious to move into democratic style countries and bleed the fiscal taxation systems dry, remove from countries such as Australia large amounts of capital into tax havens of the world and then move off-shore in the hope of avoiding the due punishment and retribution they deserve. It has been a loophole in the Act in the past. I am very pleased to see this very positive step to have that position remedied.

Like the other speakers who have taken part in this debate today, I do not intend to exercise my right to speak for 20 minutes. I think that the Bill is highly commendable. I do not agree that this Government has been slow to act in the past. We have had only 20 months in government. Sometimes the Opposition tends to forget that. I am sure that the honourable member for Menzies, in his term as Attorney-General, was well aware of the time and detail involved in getting paperwork moving through the system. I see that he happily nods his head in agreement. I am rather pleased that in such a short space of time, the Government has moved in this manner and with the speed it has to get the amendment up. I am sure that the matters which have been raised by honourable members opposite in the debate will be attended to in the future. I am sure that the Attorney-General will handle those matters and give the information required. I commend the Bill to the House.

To that extent I applaud the Government for bringing in this legislation which will assist in some measure in achieving this. As the Attorney-General mentioned in his second reading speech, the legislation provides for amendments to the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966 and the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of the same year. SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned, as indeed are other members of the Opposition, over the removal of the role of the magistrates in determining what are offences of a political character. As the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) mentioned, the Attorney-General has always had the authority to determine finally whether anyone ought to be extradited. However, we on this side are loath to see this area removed from the courts. The Attorney-General has ample time and discretion to determine whether someone ought to be extradited. I am a little concerned at the fact that some totalitarian and Marxist countries in the world might not have the tradition of respect for the rule of law that we on this side of the chamber and some honourable members opposite share. TALK.START.PARA: —Like the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), who has just concluded his speech, I do not intend to canvass at length the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill 1985 and the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Bill 1985. We would certainly be speedsters compared with the coalition governments, which took nearly a century to amend the legislation. It is interesting to note what the then Attorney-General had to say in 1966. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill now before the House is concerned with extradition between Commonwealth countries. Its introduction follows two conferences between Commonwealth Law Ministers. The first discussion took place in Canberra in September 1965 when the Commonwealth Law Ministers were here at the invitation of the Australian Government following the Commonwealth and Empire Law Conference in Sydney.
It seems that the conference had to be held in Sydney to spur things along. The then Attorney-General continued:

Law Ministers then recommended to their Governments that a special conference should be convened in 1966 to complete a scheme of extradition arrangements between Commonwealth countries. The second conference . . . was held in London in April of this year.
That is 1966. He continued:
The Bill is designed to give effect to the scheme worked out in detail in London.

Consequently all Commonwealth countries have based their domestic extradition legislation, insofar as it relates to extradition with other Commonwealth countries, on the London scheme. In 1983 Commonwealth Law Ministers met to review the London scheme and agreed to certain changes to it to improve its operation. Putting these changes into effect requires amendment to the legislation of the various Commonwealth countries. The legislation now before us provides for the amendments to the Australian legislation to which I have previously referred. I wish once again to quote what was said by the then Attorney-General in 1966 in respect of what I think is the basis of extradition law. He said:

A proper scheme of extradition must, as honourable members will perceive, satisfy two interests. There is first the interest that the peoples of all countries have in ensuring that acts that are universally considered as crimes should not go unpunished. On the other hand, it is necessary to ensure that there are adequate safeguards to protect the interests of the person whose surrender is sought. A request for surrender, for example, that is made for ulterior reasons clearly ought not to be acceded to. The scheme worked out in London . . . takes due account of both interests.

I believe the amendments encompassed in the Bills now before the House take those two principles into account. However, because of dramatic changes in our society, including international travel, the spread of crime on an international base and the sophistication of international crime rings, legislative streamlining was inevitable. I trust that this Government in its fight against organised crime will continue to review this legislation on a regular basis.

In speaking to the Bills in this place in 1966, Mr Whitlam, the then honourable member for Werriwa and, of course, a well-respected and prominent jurist of his time, referred to what was then the dormant state of extradition and argued that in the circumstances the Bills of the day were not likely to arouse public interest. This is in stark contrast to the problems that confront the Government at present. The honourable member, who subsequently became the leader of this nation, went on to say:

They are, however, Bills which can be brought into the limelight overnight. I think we can be confident that the next time a crisis arises in these fields-because they are always crises, there is never a trivial case of extradition-Australia will be in a better position both to ensure that persons who committed crimes in Australia are brought to book and to ensure that persons who are alleged to have committed crimes overseas and who are now in Australia are not extradited except for good reason.
These words, of course, echoed those of the Attorney-General of the day.

I would like to refer briefly to the amending legislation before us. Initially I will speak to the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill. Under the present legislation, if a magistrate declines to commit a fugitive to await a warrant for surrender to the requesting country, that country has no right to seek review of that decision. Notwithstanding that, the fugitive may challenge the magistrate's decision by applying to the Supreme Court of the jurisdiction in which he is held for a writ of habeas corpus. The proposed amendment will allow-I note there is no conflict in this regard-a review of questions of law and questions of fact by the Supreme Court at the instance of the requesting country.

I will now turn to the discretion placed in the Executive to refuse extradition. The present Act vests in the Attorney-General, magistrate and the court to which application is made for a writ of habeas corpus the power to refuse to surrender a person if satisfied that the offence is trivial, that the accusation was not made in good faith or in the interests of justice, or that the time which has elapsed since the offence was committed is such that, having regard to the circumstances of the Commission of the offence, it would be unjust and oppressive or too severe a punishment to surrender the person. It is clear that there are circumstances not covered by these specific instances. Those circumstances would make it unjust to surrender the fugitive and provision is made that surrender should be able to be refused for any other sufficient cause. I emphasise the words 'sufficient cause'. This amendment extends the Attorney-General's discretion in any situation where it would be unjust or oppressive to grant extradition. This extent of power given to the Attorney-General at present provides that the discretion may be exercised only where the triviality of the offence, malafides or lapses of time would make it unjust or oppressive to grant extradition.

It is clear under extradition law that the hearing for extradition is not intended to determine the guilt or innocence of the fugitive but rather whether the case extends to justify the fugitive's trial in the requesting country. Magistrates have in the past, as a matter of precedence, permitted fugitives to lead evidence to challenge the merits of the prima facie case sought to be established by the requesting country. Amendments included in this Bill make it clear that such evidence may not be led. The fugitive, of course, still has the right to argue that the prima facie case has not been established.

Finally, in relation to the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill, I briefly refer to an important principle embodied under the provisions of the specialty role. This amendment makes it clear that no longer is it necessary for an extradited person to be given an opportunity of returning to the requesting country before being tried for any offence other than the offence in respect of which extradition was sought. The amendment now provides that the extradited person is to be given an opportunity of leaving the requesting country.

I am proud of the accomplishments of this Government. I am not suggesting for one moment that we have exhausted all avenues and that all that has to be done has been done-far from it. We need only to look at the words of Mr Whitlam to see how things can change overnight in this field. That is why I ask this Government and any future government to keep in mind the fact that we must continually and regularly review the provisions of the extradition law. I note that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who is present in the chamber, took part in the debate in 1966 and obviously would have added some quite positive comments to that debate. He is still with us some 19 years later debating these Bills. I note with interest and with some degree of comfort what he said the other day when he was announcing the Government's initiatives on extradition and the agreement reached with Finland. I wish to quote what the Attorney-General said on that occasion. I think they are sobering thoughts. He said:
There is an increasing international element in major crime today, and in particular major crime involving illicit dealing in narcotic drugs.
We must be able to effectively apprehend our fugitives overseas and return them to Australia to be dealt with under our law.
The amendments to the extradition laws will assist in that process, in particular, by providing a proper base for the Task Force--
another initiative of this Attorney-General-
to negotiate efficient modern extradition arrangements with overseas countries. The treaty with Finland is a good example.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an unusual field for a non-lawyer such as myself to enter into. However, I feel that the extradition amendments before the House warrant some comment from a non-lawyer. The original legislation is old and warrants review. The Government has set about to make that review. Some of the main aspects of the review were notified to the Press by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on 13 February this year when he was in a shade of bother concerning the extradition of Mr Trimbole. The Attorney-General at that stage drew the attention of the Australian people to the amendments that he proposed to the extradition laws.

SPEECH.PARA: The first amendment the Attorney is in the process of having executed in the House today enables Australia to conclude a no list treaty whereby the offences for which extradition is granted are not listed in a Schedule attached to the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Bill. Instead a blanket cover is substituted covering all offences with penalties of imprisonment ranging from 12 months to life as being offences which will warrant extradition. One notable exception is dealt with in the memorandum attached to the Bill; that is, the assassination of a foreign head of state. That provision has been removed, but there is a note in the memorandum saying that the Attorney-General has power to make a decision anyway. Genocide remains as one of the extraditable offences but the assassination of a head of state has been taken out of section 9 of the principal Act. I cannot quite follow the logic in that process. Both are abominable crimes and I would have thought that we would have demonstrated our bona fides by giving a firm commitment to people with whom we are engaging in treaties by saying: 'If your head of state is assassinated by an Australian, extradition should take place'. I accept the maintenance of genocide as a non-political action for the purposes of this legislation. The Bill refers to 'an offence of a political character'. For the purposes of the Bill, genocide is removed from the provisions of political activity and assessed as being deplorable, enabling extradition to take place. The assassination of a head of state is not included. I think that is an oversight. The memorandum indicates that it may be an oversight. I believe that it could be a significant factor when negotiating treaties.

The second main feature which the Attorney drew to the attention of the Australian people in the process of re-examining the extradition (Foreign States) legislation was the amendment to facilitate extradition arrangements with countries with a European legal tradition by making allowance for the differences in approach to evidence in preliminary hearings adopted in those countries. Certainly, the current Act displays that character in that there is no need to provide evidence but the copy of the warrant for arrest and other legal processes can be presented to the Attorney-General or an Australian magistrate and extradition can follow from that. I have no objection to that process. It simplifies the extradition process because the different processes of law in countries around the world will necessitate a different approach. The Government is to be commended for that.

The no list approach, I think, is warranted. I, like the shadow Attorney-General, cannot quite understand why it has been done. I look forward to the explanation from the Attorney on that matter. I draw to his attention the question of the assassination of a head of state. I think we should reactivate that. I am not moving an amendment along those lines, but perhaps between this House and the other place the Attorney should consider whether that section is not reactivated.

I speak in regard to this matter mainly because of my concern at what I would term some lethargy on the part of the Government. I am not as critical as some of my colleagues of the slowness of the Government in making these amendments. I do not wish that to be misunderstood. The report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking came down at the very end of 1983 and was not a matter for the previous Government. Things move slowly in government, but we knew that significant criminals who were former Australian residents were living overseas. Mr Justice Stewart drew attention to these matters and to the precise changes that he recommended for our extradition processes. He drew particular attention to the specific matters that he thought ought to be amended. The Government has taken no action. It has a model treaty and buried somewhere in its departments are some proposed amendments to the principal Act.

It all came too late for Mr Robert Trimbole. The honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) said that it was a constitutional matter that prevented the extradition of Trimbole. That is partly true but not completely true. The fact is that Trimbole was arrested under Irish law for possessing arms and for running drugs. He was let go and re-arrested when the treaty arrangements with Ireland had been processed. He was then brought before the court on the basis of extradition arrangements which were instigated by the Australian Government. The American Government was also watching these processes very carefully because it was concerned that some legality, some slip of the legal process, could mean that wanted criminals from the United States sojourning in Ireland could also escape the net by using a similar process to the one that Trimbole used.

I believe that the Government could have been far more active. It is a great shame if there is criticism against the Australian Administration over that matter and we are seen to be wanting in the pursuit of criminals of Trimbole's type. Trimbole has a name that is recognised right throughout Australia. He has been said to have been responsible for some dreadful things, including the murder, or the arrangement of the murder, of Donald Mackay. The only government that has not been very active in this field is the Government of New South Wales. It should have been far more active in pressing the Australian Government to expedite changes to extradition law. The slowness in moving in this area extends to many other areas in which extradition law could also be affected.

The change from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to the National Crime Authority has been slow, painstaking and has produced little action. The Government has not been active in pursuing recommendations made by Costigan as well as by Stewart. In fact, in November last the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that if re-elected he would introduce laws related to recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission. Those laws relate to the prevention of extortion by unionists, the debarring from office of officials convicted of indictable offences, compensation for victims, and other matters with which the Government should be proceeding. The Government should have a checklist of measures it needs to adopt in all areas.

In the Attorney-General's area, if there had been a checklist of matters raised by Costigan, Stewart and others so that regular progress could have been reported to the Government, I am sure this matter would not have occurred. I am sure that the failure by the Australian authorities to have an effective extradition process with the Republic of Ireland would not have happened if there was a regular check. I say to the Attorney-General that I believe in government he needs to cover areas of significance in crime. He must have regular reports on what the Australian Federal Police are doing. He must have regular assessments of where changes to legislation are in the system so that the Government can exert pressure and make progress, and so that those changes are instigated in this Parliament.

I believe that, outside that area, the Government also has to be able to get reports from various Ministers as to what their departments are doing. The Attorney-General's Department is a significant one-and should report on where it is going with prosecutions, preparation of papers and the expedition of cases that are being heard in the courts. The Special Prosecutor, Mr Gyles, had that responsibility. Reports should be coming from him as well as from Mr Ian Temby. Unless the Government is watching all of these matters week by week, month by month, it will find that in two years time there will be another instance like the Trimbole instance because the Government has failed to be active, concerned and diligent in every area of the pursuit and prevention of major crime in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all members for their contribution to this debate. It has been wide-ranging and has raised a number of matters which everybody would like me to answer. I do not know whether I can answer all of them to the satisfaction of honourable members. I commence with the remarks of the last speaker, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). I appreciate his remarks. They were very apt. He wanted particularly to know why the provisions dealing with genocide and the assassination of a head of state were being removed from the legislation. Those provisions are being changed only in the sense of their not being political offences. They are still offences in the sense that they are murder. There is no difficulty about that matter. They are not deemed to be political offences in that sense.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member raised a matter relating to Trimbole, and I suppose we tend to get political about this matter. Let me make the point that Trimbole left Australia in 1981. Some of the offences, particularly the Wilson murders, were committed in 1980. They, of course, occurred in Victoria. The honourable member should not get too blinkered in thinking that all problems relate to New South Wales. He must also understand that Commonwealth warrants were issued too for offences under Commonwealth law. Really, the issue is that the man had good legal advice about where we did not have treaties. I applaud what the honourable member said. It is important to keep up a monitoring arrangement. In the case of Ireland, for example, a treaty was concluded in 1977 and lost. That must astound honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —And lost?

—Lost in the sense that nobody bothered to bring it out of the drawer. It was concluded but not brought into action. I am not making any complaints, but honourable members know who was in government from 1977 until we took over. I have to tell the House these things, although not in any vitriolic sense, because the same thing could happen to me. However, let me make it clear that in the Trimbole case the Attorney-General's Department worked very hard and assiduously and, in fact, brought into operation treaty arrangements which allowed our warrants to be valid. The difficulty in that case is a legal one, which I think will be decided this evening, as a matter of interest. Whether Mr Trimbole will be present to hear the verdict is another matter. The problem was that because he was arrested for an offence that was not able to be proven under Irish law-it did not relate to our warrants but to an Irish offence-there was deemed to be the taint of illegality. There was a rather unusual decision that that taint of illegality prevented our warrants coming into operation. The point the honourable member made was valid in that we live in a world in which modern transport makes countries very close. People travel across the world very rapidly. Criminals, particularly those dealing in narcotics, use all the available conveyances to get in and out of countries very quickly indeed. This week we had the benefit of concluding a treaty with Finland, which is interesting. I imagine that people would be thinking that 30 or 40 years ago nobody was interested in looking at that problem, but it is very much alive today.

SPEECH.PARA: The contributions made by my colleagues and also by those opposite have been very valuable in making the public aware that this is an ongoing operation. What we are about in this legislation is making amendments to two existing pieces of legislation virtually to update them. This will allow us to negotiate more effective treaties than those we now have. As a Commonwealth country we inherited what are called the Commonwealth country treaties-35 in number. They are a little outmoded because they relate to what are called specific offences and not necessarily to what we would be looking at in a more modern situation-offences punishable by a sentence of 12 months imprisonment or more, which avoids the list. In other words, one has a difficulty if one is trying to talk about what is on the list. If an Australian offence is not on the list of the other country we are in jeopardy. We have overcome that problem.

Let me now deal with the matters raised by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), who led the debate for the Opposition. One matter was a query about voluntary return. I am advised that it is availed of by a number of fugitives each year, so it is of practical benefit. He then raised a couple of other matters related to the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. One related to the recommendation that trials be held in the absence of the accused who is unable to be found or is imprisoned overseas. I am advised that the Government rejected that recommendation in an announcement in the Senate in December 1983. It did so for the reason that it was deemed to be contrary to our standard of proof and our standard of law that a person could be tried in his absence. The proposition that people could be tried in their absence was also deemed to be a breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. So we have a difficulty in proceeding with a trial when a person is imprisoned overseas. A statement was made in the Senate to that effect by the previous Attorney-General.

A point was raised about the recommendation that the Attorney-General's Department monitor all extraditions. That is being done; I am assured that that is the position. The honourable member also asked about defining an extraditable crime by reference to a penalty of 12 months or more imprisonment. He asked why a lesser penalty should not warrant extradition. I remind the honourable gentleman that at present under the provisions of section 19 of the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act and under a section of the Extradition (Foreign States) Act an extraditable offence is defined as being an offence that carries a penalty of 12 months or more imprisonment because it is thought that any lesser penalty would relate to a much lesser offence that would not warrant extradition.

As to the point about bringing back people from overseas, we are anxious to do that through the modern concept of mutual assistance treaties, particularly in criminal matters, so that we can bring people back to Australia to give evidence to assist justice in this country. So it is a matter that is very much to the fore. In the mutual assistance area it would require other countries to give us assistance, particularly in respect of financial records and other matters. Switzerland is a case in point. It might be appropriate to mention that I understand the United States of America is about to conclude, if it has not already, a mutual assistance treaty with Switzerland. In that context there would be opportunities to bring people back here on the basis of getting evidence and records.

I make the point, as I have already told the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), that I accept his proposed amendments. I note that they relate to a clear recognition that in matters of political offences there might be a suggestion that another offence might be used which could be a subterfuge for a political offence. I am reminded that in February of this year a paper was circulated in the United Kingdom which covers this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is the extradition one.

—Yes, and it makes the point, as the honourable member has said, that this is an appropriate way to talk about the offences of a political character. Apparently it has been in the British extradition Act since 1870. The paper makes the point that the Act does not define the expression 'political character' and judicial interpretation has demonstrated the difficulty of devising a satisfactory definition. Nevertheless, I will accept it. The courts have, however, recognised the need to preserve the freedom to grant political asylum in appropriate cases. I thank the honourable gentleman for his contribution. I think it will be a worthwhile addition as in no way does it detract from the fact that I would also have a discretion. Irrespective of that, if a decision went the wrong way, from the point of view of judging the political issue, in other words if the court rejected it, I could still have a chance to look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the main thrust of the debate was whether we were just grandstanding, if Opposition members want to put it that way, or whether we were making effective progress. I think we are making effective progress. I have some notes here which clearly indicate what I think honourable members opposite are all about. An extradition hearing is not a trial of guilt or innocence, it is simply a procedure to enable a person to be returned to the appropriate jurisdiction for charges against him or her to be determined. The difficulty we are having is that civil law countries have different legal systems and they have had considerable difficulty in furnishing evidence in the form or of the standard that we have always insisted upon. There are now amendments that will facilitate the conclusion of treaties which we otherwise could not have entered into because of that situation.

Requests for extradition will still have to supply a full statement of the facts alleged against a fugitive. Under already existing treaties that statement must be in the form of prima facie evidence as for a committal hearing. So all present safeguards are being retained in negotiating treaties. Regard will be had to the justice system in the country concerned. I think it was the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) who raised the issue of African countries. We must acknowledge that there is a lack of treaties with a number of African countries. We would be very anxious to achieve success there and we are going to work at that. The idea of having the no-list amendment gives greater flexibility and it will again facilitate treaty negotiations in that time does not have to be spent on agreeing to a form of words to cover an offence which although penalising the same conduct is described in a different way.

A proceeding for the taking of evidence for an extradition request is not a trial, as we have said, but it is generally understood that fugitives should not be able formally to appear at such proceedings. The amendment we have moved makes this clear, and it is in accordance with the decision of the Federal Court of Australia in Trimbole v. Dugan, as the former Attorney-General decided on 2 November 1984. If fugitives have a right of appearance it could be possible they could delay the proceedings for a sufficient time to ensure that Australia would not be able to comply with its obligations to make a formal request, supported by evidence, to another country within the time limits imposed by that country.

On the question of fugitives not giving evidence, I inform honourable members that an extradition hearing is initiated by a request from another country, but the matter is handled by the Australian authorities. If the fugitive wishes to controvert the material alleged against him the appropriate place for that to be done is in the country where the trial is to take place. It is generally understood that fugitives should not be able to challenge the merits of a case presented in the extradition hearing.

On the question of bail, the two Acts provide that the magistrate may grant bail. There was a decision in Queensland where it was held that the Supreme Court may not grant bail. The case was called Re: Groves. This amendment simply confirms that judgment. In no way does it take away a fugitive's right to review a decision of a magistrate by way of habeas corpus. At present a fugitive may make application for habeas corpus in a State Supreme Court and at the same time apply to the Federal Court for judicial review of the magistrate's decision. The same issues would be involved in each application. The amendment simply prevents duplicity of remedy as the use of that duplicity can be a delaying tactic.

Having restated those matters I finish by mentioning what progress has been made in the extradition task force. I am reminded that the task force was established as recently as the 15th of last month. It comprises officers of the Attorney-General's department and the Department of Foreign Affairs. In that short space of time this task force has settled a draft model treaty which will be the basis of negotiations with foreign states for modern extradition treaties. A number of approaches have been made to European countries opening the way for discussion in relation to modern bilateral treaties. A proposal has already been put to and is being considered by officials of the Federal Republic of Germany and which, if accepted, will facilitate extradition between Australia and that country, pending the coming into force of a treaty between the two countries. Draft regulations have been prepared for the approval of the Governor-General extending the application of the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act to 14 Commonwealth countries not presently declared under that Act. Discussions have taken place with the Republic of South Africa on the basis of extradition. There has been a thorough investigation into the status of Australia's extradition arrangements with former colonies of the metropolitan powers of France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium and the Netherlands, which may have succeeded to extradition treaties entered into by the relevant metropolitan powers and Great Britain. Australia may have effective extradition arrangements with such of the former colonies which recognise double succession in relation to extradition treaties.

Work has been completed on Bills which substantially amend the two Acts. The possibility of a number of countries applying the Extradition (Foreign States) Act to those countries to enable extradition to take place on the basis of reciprocity has been investigated. Discussions are also taking place with the United States and Britain in relation to extradition generally. I mention that only to show that a lot of work has been done because it is urgent and it should have been done long ago. The delay and the faults have been recognised. I commend my Department and its officials for their enthusiasm and assistance in this regard and I thank honourable members for their contribution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

The Opposition's amendments, as the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) has explained under a division of labour between the two of us, have already been explained to the House and I shall be extremely brief. The effects of the amendments are: First, the role of the courts is preserved; and secondly, an additional safeguard which, as the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has pointed out, is taken from the 1870 extradition Act of the United Kingdom Parliament, is brought into play, where the surrender has in fact been made, by the addition of the words:
. . . that the requisition for his surrender has in fact been made with a view to try or punish him for an offence of a political character.

One cannot be too cautious in these matters. One can easily find cases in which extradition is made under the guise that a criminal offence has been committed, but the fact is that it is simply dressed up for the purposes of seeking to get a person returned to his country for political reasons and to be dealt with for a political offence.

The amendments preserve the proposed powers which will be vested in the Attorney-General so that he can conclude that the offence in question is in effect a political offence, even though the court might come to the opposite conclusion. Therefore, we have two general safeguards: Firstly, the courts can conclude that the offence in question is an offence of a political character; secondly, even when the court does not reach that conclusion, the Attorney-General can. And, as the Attorney-General has said, there may be cases in which courts will not have the material before them and, indeed, cases in which courts will not be as politically astute or as politically well versed as an Attorney-General may be expected to be. That being said, I do not think it is necessary to say anything more about these amendments. They are perfectly clear and I am very glad that the Attorney-General has taken the course of adopting the Opposition's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the non-list process. I listened very carefully to the comments made by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and wish to draw further matters to his attention. It does seem to me that the process of extradition draws back to Australia criminals who have committed offences in Australia, or other countries take back to their soil people who have committed offences there and who have been detected or apprehended in Australia. The list process that is contained in the current legislation lists a series of offences for which the extradition process may be triggered. That process, once triggered, is then executed by the Attorney-General by the issue of a warrant of apprehension, a warrant of commitment or other similar process. If the Attorney issues a warrant of apprehension, it involves the bringing back to Australia of somebody who has committed an offence in another land but who has a record within Australia that makes us want to have him returned. The Attorney-General has dispensed with the list process which in the current legislation gives details of those offences for which we can draw people back to Australia-and they are written into the treaties of agreement-or for which people can extract from Australia criminals or people who have committed offences.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to draw to the attention of the Attorney-General some of the difficulties I see in regard to the non-list process, which provides that an offence which carries a penalty of 12 months imprisonment is the minimum for which that extradition process can be triggered. Why should not a person who commits that new offence be subject to extradition, despite the fact that the penalty is less than 12 months imprisonment? That is one of the points that we are putting.
