TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill. The reasons which ordinarily I would advance will, in the interests of time, be advanced by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I make one observation, which I hope the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) will respond to at the end of the debate, concerning a widespread public concern about the use to which Australian foreign aid is put, whether it is bilateral aid or multilateral aid through agencies such as that which is the subject of this Bill. Of course, the bilateral aid question is addressed in the report of the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program. That Committee report is now being processed by a joint House all-party committee of this Parliament. It will be a matter for debate in this Parliament later in the year.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of grants to the International Development Agency or any other multilateral organisation, even though they are praised in the Jackson report as being efficient and even though their programs over the years have been effective, I believe that because of the level of disquiet now being expressed in Australia, the Minister owes it to the Australian taxpayer to make a report on the nature of projects which benefit under the grants which are the subject of this Bill. I am not suggesting that the Australian money should be traced as it goes into projects, but I am suggesting that the kinds of projects which will be the subject of long term interest-free loans as a result of grants of this character by Australia to the World Bank be reported upon.

I illustrate the argument by reference to Ethiopia. The fact is that potentially Ethiopia can support its large population. With the right economic and technical policies, it undoubtedly could support its population rather than suffer, as is now happening, the most tragic results of a famine. The famine, according to all objective observers, is as much as anything government-induced. It is important that if we are to go on meeting, as we must, short term food and other aid requirements of those who are the victims of that famine and therefore of that economic mismanagement, the Australian public, knowing that the transportation costs alone are massive even once the aid gets to Ethiopia, is entitled to be informed that, concurrent with that short term aid, projects which are capable of leading to a self-sustaining economy are being undertaken with aid money such as that which is the subject of this Bill.

I hope that the Minister will look at that suggestion and undertake to report to the Parliament in one form or another, perhaps in the context of the overall foreign aid debate that must ensue from the Government's ultimate action on the recommendations of the Jackson report. It is important that Australians understand where aid of this character, as well as short term food aid, is going. In the interest of saving time in this debate, as there is no contest between the Opposition and the Government, I am simply content to identify myself with the reasons advanced by the honourable member for Mayo when his turn comes to participate in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill 1985 is designed to make it possible for Australia to allocate, in addition to the $200m which we provided following agreement to do so last year in the seventh replenishment of the Association, an additional voluntary contribution of $60m towards the resources of that Association. A whole range of agencies, arrangements and authorities exist throughout the world and are designed, at least in part, to provide the machinery through which assistance can be channelled from those countries which enjoy a relatively high gross domestic product to those developing countries which are in need of various kinds of assistance. The International Development Association is the concessional lending agency of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development-more generally known as the World Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: The Association began operation in November 1960. Its assistance is particularly aimed at the poorer developing countries among its over 130 members. In 1980 terms-I am sorry to say that I do not have more recent figures in this context-the purpose of the Association was to assist those countries whose per capita income was less than $US750. The significance of that amount becomes apparent when one realises that in 1980, expressed in the same monetary terms, the world average for gross domestic product per capita was $US2,600, and for the developed countries the average was $US8,500. I emphasise that this particular Association accepts the responsibility of assisting those countries whose per capita income in United States dollars in 1980 terms was only $US750. The significance of that should not be lost to honourable members or to the Australian community.

Perhaps more than any other agency which exists in the world the International Development Association is concerned with directing assistance to those parts of the world and those communities and countries where assistance clearly is most needed. The terms under which that assistance is made available are much more favourable than the terms under which the assistance is made available to other countries from the World Bank itself. In the first place the Association provides loans for a longer period. In general, the period is up to 50 years, with an additional 10 years grace which is allowed for the maturing of those loans. Furthermore, the loans are interest-free.

The resources of the International Development Association come mainly from the subscriptions of the industrialised countries which pledge periodic general replenishments. This legislation provides for a supplement to the $200m which Australia provided as a result of legislation passed last year towards the seventh replenishment of the Association since it began operations in late 1960. The sixth replenishment-that is the main means by which the Association obtains funds-covering the years 1981 to 1983 was $12,000m. That money came from all the developed countries from in excess of 130 countries that make up the total membership of the Association. The most recent replenishment, the seventh-this gives the background to the reason why Australia has agreed to make this voluntary supplementary grant available-was designed to cover commitments during the period 1985 to 1987. That sum was to be only $9,000m. That was a major reduction not only in monetary terms but in real terms. That $9,000m limit was brought about through the reluctance of the United States of America to increase the volume of its contribution. If the developed country members of the Association had maintained in real terms the value of the previous replenishment, we would have been providing not $9,000m but $15,000m. Therefore, there has been a significant reduction in the type of funds necessary on the part of organisations of that kind to fulfil the important responsibilities with which they have been charged by the world community.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is by all of us.

—Yes, by all of us collectively. That undertaking has been accepted by the world community, including Australia. Although some concerns have been expressed about the place of Australia and the volume of its support, I stress that we are one of the better countries of the world in terms of the type and volume of assistance per head that we make available. With some significant reservations, we can be quite proud of the type and nature of the contribution we make to our responsibilities under those arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the reduced real value of the contribution, Australia and a number of other countries became concerned about the impact, the effect, that that reduced replenishment would have. In the light of the urgent needs of the recipient countries, countries which benefit from the funds of the Association, Australia decided to supplement the assistance it was providing. As I have said, this legislation provides for $60m in addition to the $200m we authorised last year.

There were two ways in which we could have provided the additional assistance. The first was through a multilateral funding facility which has recently been established to assist sub-Saharan Africa. If we had made that money available through that facility, it would have meant quite clearly that the additional funds we were providing would have been restricted to that area. Of course, that is a very deserving area. We are familiar with some of the very serious and growing disabilities that the millions of people in that sub-Saharan region are experiencing at present. We preferred, however, to make the funds available in an untied way to the general resources of the Association. In that way some funds will go to the sub-Saharan region and the additional funds will assist in providing aid to some of those deprived areas closer to Australia and within our own region. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) during his second reading speech said:
The impoverished countries of the world depend upon IDA for development assistance on concessional terms.
He went on to say:

Australia's voluntary contribution will emphasise our commitment to assist the poorest countries; it will also underline the importance we attach to IDA as a source of development assistance for these countries. This Bill therefore provides Australia with the means to achieve these major humanitarian objectives through established cost effective means.

I believe, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs quite clearly believes, that the way in which we have made this special assistance available is the most appropriate. Evidence of the concentration of IDA assistance on the poorest countries is provided in the following information: In the year to 30 June 1982, for example, 90 per cent of IDA funds went to countries with a per capita gross national product of less than $410. It is hard, in fact it is almost impossible, for people in Australia to comprehend the significance of a per capita income of $410. I will give figures later on to indicate that per capita income falls significantly below the figure in many of the most impoverished countries for many of the most impoverished people in the world.

In the year to June 1982 the IDA contribution supported 97 projects in 42 different countries. During that same period, when the disbursements represented just over $2,000m, the largest proportion, which went to assist agricultural projects, accounted for 44 per cent of the total disbursements. Power projects took 20 per cent, transport projects took 10 per cent and education projects took 5 per cent. So it is quite clear that the funds of the IDA are being directed towards the most important types of projects within those underdeveloped countries.

In recent years we have become aware of the growing burden of the foreign debt of developing countries. For example, since 1970 the total outstanding debt for the Third World-the underdeveloped or developing countries of the world-went from $70 billion to $600 billion. The debt servicing costs for those countries as a percentage of their gross domestic product went from 2 per cent to over 5 per cent. This occurred in a period of marginally in excess of 10 years. Those countries' debt servicing costs as a percentage of their exports went from 13 per cent to over 20 per cent. The Third World debtor countries, having incurred an increasing debt of that kind, must now provide in excess of 20 per cent of their total exports just to meet their interest burden-the servicing costs of their debts. So the extent to which their exports can be made available to make it possible for them to import the types of capital equipment they need, the additional consumer goods they need, is significantly reduced.

In Australia we talk of having almost three million people living in poverty. It should cause deep concern to all Australians that, in a comparative sense, one in every five Australians lives in poverty. But it is a comparative sense. When talking about almost three million people living in poverty in Australia, we are talking in terms of them living in poverty in relation to other Australians. It is not and cannot be an objective assessment of poverty in comparison with people who live in real, grinding poverty in so many parts of the world. If we were to take a deprived and seriously underprivileged family from one of our communities in Australia and suddenly transport that family, with all of the services, the facilities and the limited assets and spending power available to it, to a village in India, those people would be the richest people in the village. In the first place, they would have clear, clean, laid-on water. They would have power. In general, they would have-

TALK.START.PARA: —Education.

—They would have compulsory education. They would have access to top class health facilities. They would have access to doctors. They would have reasonable accommodation. Possibly-most likely-they would have a television set, even if it was just black and white. They would possibly have a motor car and household furniture. When we are talking about objective poverty throughout the world, we are talking about people who have none of those things, people who are lucky to have a rag on their backs.

SPEECH.PARA: We talk in terms of the global village, the contracting globe. We are not prepared to tolerate, as we should not tolerate, our neighbours living in the type of poverty to which I have referred. When we talk about the global village we refer to the speed with which we can move from one place in the world to another and we should remember that those people about whom I have been speaking are not very far away. We could leave Australia now and within 21 hours be in Ethiopia, where people are starving. It no longer takes months to get to these places. That is how close they are. Of course, Ethiopia is around the other side of the world. There are other places much closer to us where people are in similar circumstances, and it takes us much less time to get there. These places are not divorced from us. They are very close to us.

Mr Deputy Speaker, in the limited time that is available to me, I do not wish to give the impression that I do not believe that countries in this world are justified in undertaking defence expenditure. I just wish to put it into perspective. I want to relate poverty to defence expenditure, because I know that there are increasing numbers of people throughout the world who are concerned about the massive volumes of money and resources that are being applied to military budgets when the sort of poverty to which I have been referring still exists. For example, world military expenditure in 1981 represented almost $600 billion-$600,000m. That represented 5 per cent of the world's gross domestic product. At the same time the world provided only $36 billion in aid to countries. That is 0.3 per cent of the world's gross domestic product.

Of the 4.5 billion people on earth, one billion-1,000 million of them-belong to developed countries. The vast majority, the other three-quarters, of the world's people belong to what we call developing countries, although some of them are developing very, very slowly. Of that 3,500 million people there are 450 million to 500 million people who at this very moment are starving. I am not talking about people going without a meal; I am talking about people who are starving and who have no opportunity at all of being provided with the type of food that we might expect.

I said that the per capita income of those developed countries was $US8,500 per year. For the developing countries it is about $800. I said that I would give some examples of some of those countries where it is significantly less. Is it possible for anyone in Australia who has not been to these places to understand and comprehend the significance of the plight of people in a country like Laos where the per capita income per year is $87?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a communist country.

—It is not even $2 a week. An honourable member has just stated that Laos is a communist country. That is a rather foolish type of interjection to make. Bangladesh has a per capita annual income of $129. Chad has a per capita annual income of $113. Australia has an annual per capita income of $10,000. As a result of this legislation we are making available $60m to assist those people. The significance of all these things can be compounded time after time.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that world military expenditure at present is $600,000m every year. The world spends $1.6 billion every day. We spend $1.2m every minute. I conclude by making the point that every minute 30 children die for the want of food and for the want of inexpensive vaccines. During the 20 minutes that I have been speaking the world will have spent $24m on military purposes and 600 children in the world will have died. Six hundred children died in the 20 minutes before I commenced speaking and 600 children will die during the next 20 minutes. Six hundred children will have died for the want of food and for the want of those cheap vaccines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Development Association was created just over 24 years ago to fill a void in the dealings of the World Bank with the lowest income level, lesser developed countries. The International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill intends to top up Australia's seventh increment of $200m by a further $60m. Each three years the subscriber countries, of which Australia is one, replenish the Association's funds. This year's and last year's contribution will go towards coping with the needs of the IDA over the three-year period commencing 1 July 1984. Although Australia has been a donor country since the inception of the Association, the Bill involves one of those items of expenditure which has escaped close examination and debate. That is probably because the enabling legislation only comes before the Parliament every three years.

SPEECH.PARA: It is to be regretted that expenditure of $260m of taxpayers' money over the next three years, which in reality is part of our overseas aid program, does not seem to have warranted the close scrutiny of the Parliament. That regret is only partly based on the fact that Australia is a major contributor by world standards. In the financial year to 30 June 1984 Australia was about the eleventh most generous country, despite having something like the fifteenth or sixteenth highest living standard in the world. It is important to note that until quite recently the United States was the major contributor to IDA and its affiliated bodies. However, Congress has lately reduced the United States degree of participation for reasons which cannot be entirely ignored. Without making value judgments on the reticence of the United States Congress, it may be useful to go over some details which might balance what is, after all, an almost unquestioning Australian commitment to our role in IDA.

In effect, IDA is the 'soft loan' window of the World Bank. As far as can be ascertained, it extends interest free credits for up to 50 years with a 10-year repayment grace period. The only additional cost to a recipient nation is an annual 0.75 per cent service charge on the principal. The IDA may be distinguished from another affiliate, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, for reasons which invite special attention. Unlike the IDA, the IBRD borrows on the private capital market and charges near commercial interest rates to borrowers. On the other hand, IDA credits are funded by taxpayer contributions from the donor countries, including Australia. There are about 131 member countries of the IDA, the majority of which are recipients, the remainder being donor countries which make its work possible.

The IDA, as a branch of the World Bank group, in 1973 made a commitment to what were then described as 'new style' projects. The IDA, as an affiliate of the World Bank, was given the onus for meeting this then new objective of increasing assistance with a view to solving the basic human needs of the lesser developed countries. However, there is a body of opinion in the United States and elsewhere which seriously questions whether attainment of that stated goal is now likely. An examination of the lending habits of IDA would seem to indicate that there are more questions than answers. There is certainly little in the second reading speech of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) or the explanatory memorandum which would give rise to legitimate questioning and debate. Nevertheless, that should be done, not with a partisan political objective in mind, if only because successive governments of both persuasions have co-operated in maintaining Australia's contribution over the past 24 years.

An examination of readily accessible information-there is not exactly a surfeit of it, I can assure honourable members-indicates that the main beneficiary of the IDA, and therefore Australia's contribution, is in fact India. India appears to have had the lion's share over at least a decade and probably longer. Naturally, no one denies that India is one of the world's less developed countries in many respects. However, in some ways it is not. It is not numbered amongst the least developed countries. Indeed, it must be one of the wealthiest LDCs, if that is not a contradiction to so describe it. Look at some of the national achievements of India. It has developed and tested nuclear weapons, unlike any of its near neighbours, with the exception of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and China. India and China are the only LDCs to have a known capacity to make nuclear weapons. India has one of the biggest and best equipped military forces in its region, having purchased most of its arsenal and impressive military hardware from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. India continues to enter into ongoing arms purchase agreements with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on a scale which Australia cannot hope to match, be it with the Soviet Union or any other supplier. India has a space program which progressive Australians can only dream about, particularly the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) who was so savagely rebuffed by his own Hawke socialist Government in its last Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! He was mauled.

—He was mauled, indeed. India is a major competitor of Australia in trade in some raw materials. In this context it should be remembered that much of the wealth created in Australia is generated by our extractive mining industry, which in turn enables us to embark on programs of foreign aid. If the significance of that has not dawned upon honourable members it is to be hoped that it will. Despite what are commendable technological, military and limited but significant commercial achievements, in many ways superior to our own, India lacks the ability, it seems, to resolve and successfully tackle its basic human needs requirements. It is one of the most populous poverty stricken nations on earth. Hence it qualifies to receive concessional, to the extent that they are long term and interest free, loans from IDA. Remembering Australia's not ungenerous contribution to IDA over 24 years, or 27 years after the passage of last year's Bill, it might be said that we finance a country which in some ways and in some areas has achieved more than we can possibly hope to achieve in the foreseeable future.

SPEECH.PARA: While no one could properly suggest that funds from IDA will find their way into these technological or military spending programs, equally no one could deny that such financing allows India the flexibility to order its spending priorities in a way which would be otherwise impossible. In other words, IDA loans indirectly but undeniably allow that country to do things which many may judge not to be in the best interests of either Australia or the poverty stricken masses in India we set out to help. We are, through this measure and other aid programs, indirectly financing India to develop its nuclear capacity, both military and peaceful. Australia is indirectly financing that country's rocketry and space satellite program. We are financing a massive military machine as well as the purchase of sophisticated weapons from the USSR. We are financing resources projects which will sell in direct competition with our own minerals. All that is very generous but arguably it is unwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the utter frustration of it all.

—It is frustrating. India is the example I have chosen-because it offers almost a full range of activities and programs-to illustrate the need for questioning. Nevertheless, there are many other beneficiaries which would also merit close examination for similar, if not identical, reasons. Many other LDCs have so ordered their priorities as to leave food production, housing and poverty relief well down the list, behind military expansion and nationalistic edifices. We all know of countries in the Horn of Africa, in the sub-Sahara region, indeed in the entire African continent, with armed forces of a magnitude and a standard not commensurate with their needs while, at the same time, their populations are denied more than a meagre existence. We also know of lesser developed countries which sell coal, iron ore and alumina at uneconomical prices-sometimes below the cost of production-because of an ever-increasing need for foreign currency. They sell in markets where cost efficient unsubsidised Australian producers have established, or seek to establish, a presence. The need for foreign exchange is often an overriding consideration and, in turn, is often due to a need to service both soft and hard foreign loans. Generally, there is something of a vicious circle which too often has little beneficial effect on the masses living in many LDCs.

SPEECH.PARA: One study of the International Development Association's lending program for its fiscal year 1979 seemed to highlight the need for critical concern by contributor countries such as Australia. It showed that approximately 33 per cent of IDA credits were for the purpose of agricultural and rural development, as should reasonably be expected. The chastening statistic over that admittedly limited sampling period was, however, one which showed that only a little over one per cent was allocated for population control and nutrition. At the same time, 17 per cent was to be spent on transportation, and a further 13 per cent on so-called non-projects which often provided foreign exchange for imported technology of doubtful value. It seems also that IDA credits are too widely dispersed in various economic sectors. The poorest LDCs continue to suffer from disproportionate overpopulation, malnutrition and starvation. Those three conditions require concentrated attention and will not be ameliorated merely in the light of plans for industrial progress or a professed need for technology of doubtful immediate importance or benefit.

Because Australia's voting rights in IDA are only marginally significant, it is unable to significantly influence IDA's credit allocation procedure. That procedure often produces allocations which we would not condone if our contribution were part of our direct foreign aid program. It must be at least doubtful that foreign aid channelled through a body such as IDA-over which we can exercise little control-is the best way of going about helping the poorest of developing member countries. For instance, we cannot stop IDA extending credits to Vietnam as it did a few years ago, even if as a nation we were of the opinion that such aid would only enhance that recipient country's ability to invade and occupy Kampuchea. Without debating the merits of Vietnam's invasion and occupation of its neighbour, it should be understood that Australia's views would be likely to be disregarded, despite our assessment of our own national interest. If all the $260m now pledged remained as part of our discretionary aid appropriation over the next three years, there is little doubt that our own national interest and the values of the government of the day would be taken into account when decisions on how these taxpayers' aid dollars were to be allocated.

As with many of the agencies established by the United Nations Organisation, the IDA's relevance has been only very recently seriously questioned. It has its own bureaucracy. Its deputies meet regularly in the capitals of Europe and North America but rarely, it seems, in the countries of its poorest members. That may not be significant, but the unquestioned existence and role of IDA must not be condoned. The basic premise that so-called soft loans are more beneficial to donor and recipient alike than are the alternatives of hard loans or even outright grants should be constantly under the microscope. In an article entitled 'Rethinking the Multilateral Development Banks' Professor Wilson Schmidt had this to say:

When the yield on investments in the recipient country exceeds that in the benefactor, both are better off with a hard loan because it is possible to set an interest rate between the two yields such that both parties gain.
He went on to generalise:
Paradoxical as it may seem, it is in fact cheaper to give the money away than lend it when the yield on investment in the recipient is below that in the benefactor.

In terms of IDA loans, any yields in recipient countries must certainly exceed that in the benefactor, when the benefactor is Australia and its contributions take the form of grants. We do not even get the kudos and accompanying national advantage which should accrue from unilateral or bilateral aid granted directly and not under the IDA or World Bank umbrella. The report of the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program has not yet come under close scrutiny in this Parliament; nor have its views and recommendations been acted upon by the Government. Nevertheless, it makes references relevant to the nature of our overseas aid, as well as going into a great deal of detail. While noting considerable improvement over the past decade, the Jackson report also observed that the ad hoc nature of it has persisted in many respects. It is not possible, of course, to deny that money Australia and other donor nations provide to IDA finds its way into the most impoverished nations, as intended. It may even help us garner enough votes to get Australia a seat in the United Nations Security Council. Nevertheless, whatever the real or perceived advantages for Australia, there must be some downside as well. Although these downsides may have been mentioned by other honourable members tonight, they certainly were not in the Minister's second reading speech.

The report of the Jackson Committee does, however, make distinctions between bilateral and multilateral aid directly given or granted. Unfortunately, it does not quantitatively deal with aspects of aid of the type envisaged in this Bill or possibly because of this Bill. The proposed contributions to IDA might be described as unilateral aid rendered indirectly-I repeat, 'indirectly'-to distinguish it from aid given directly, albeit either in the form of bilateral or multilateral aid. The Jackson Committee does make one observation which, if read in isolation, might give an impression that we act in accordance with Professor Schmidt's implied preferred position in suggesting that it is cheaper to give the money away rather than lend it when the yield on the investment in the recipient country is below that in the benefactor country or vice versa. Remember that the benefactor is Australia in this context. The Committee report also says:
In recent years Australia has given all its aid on grant terms.

It is important to stress that it should not be assumed by anyone that this Bill will result in aid eventually being delivered on grant terms and certainly not on Australia's terms, grant or otherwise. It is equally clear that this contribution is aid and is more importantly part of our foreign aid, regardless of any claims to the contrary. In the absence of sufficient information, it may be enough, given our earlier pledges to IDA which the Bill merely validates, to flag such questions as matters of importance. Perhaps consideration of the Jackson Committee report and the subsequent revision of our total aid program will quell any existing doubts. For humanitarian, commercial and national reasons, those doubts should be eliminated, and eliminated quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill 1985 authorises an additional contribution of $A60m to the available assets of the International Development Association or, as it is more widely known, IDA. The Australian Government has decided to make a voluntary and unilateral contribution of $A60m in addition to Australia's share totalling $A200m to the Association's seventh replenishment of the resources of IDA covering the period 1985-87. Legislation authorising the contribution by Australia of $A200m towards the seventh replenishment of the International Development Association is contained in the International Development Association (Further Payment) Act 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: A significant proportion of Australia's multilateral aid is channelled through international finance institutions. These institutions include the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank, their respective concessional lending affiliates and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. Australia is a member of the World Bank group, comprising the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which lends to its developing member countries on better than commercial terms, the International Development Association, which lends on highly concessional terms to the poorest developing countries, and the International Finance Corporation, which was set up to promote the growth of productive private enterprise in its developing member countries. As has been pointed out by a number of speakers in this debate, the International Development Association was established over 20 years ago to provide concessional assistance to low income countries. Its origins lay in the recognition that, for many of the poorest countries, private capital and existing aid arrangements were not adequate. The World Bank, which had led to multilateral aid effort after World War II, claimed that it could not lend to the poorest countries without damaging its own credit position in international capital markets. Furthermore, the low income countries could ill afford to take on loans carrying high interest rates and short maturities to finance projects with long payback periods and earning little or no foreign exchange. Donor governments agreed to the establishment of IDA because, in its affiliation with the World Bank, they saw an assurance that concessional loans would be used to finance bank-type projects.

The resources of the International Development Association come mainly from subscriptions by industrialised countries, pledged in periodic large replenishments and supplemented by transfers of net earnings through the World Bank. As the International Development Association has grown, so has the number of its donors. The initial subscription involved 17 industrial countries. Today the number of donors has nearly doubled and the list of donors includes a number of developing countries.

The size of the seventh replenishment of the resources of the International Development Association has been agreed by donors at $US9 billion. This represents a decline of $US3 billion which was provided under the sixth replenishment. Most donors, including Australia, view the $US9 billion target as gravely inadequate having regard to the pressing needs of the poorest countries for development assistance. It is believed that this will result in the level of concessional lending to the world's poorest countries being significantly reduced.

Recognising a clear need for additional resources, most donors felt that the Association's management should make further efforts to arrange supplementary financing for the fiscal 1985-87 period. Accordingly, at the International Monetary Fund-World Bank annual meetings in Washington last year, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that the Australian Government would further respond to the needs of IDA recipients by making a voluntary and unilateral special contribution to IDA. The Federal Government decided to make a unilateral and voluntary additional contribution of $A60m. This voluntary contribution does not become part of Australia's formal share in the International Development Association and is not a precedent for future burden sharing.
The announcement of Australia's contribution was well received by the World Bank. The President of the World Bank was reported as having said:

We are deeply grateful to the Government of Australia for its generous response to the overwhelming problems faced by the poorest countries, especially in the sub-Sahara and Africa. Australia's announced intention to make a voluntary and unilateral special contribution to IDA over and above the amounts already pledged to the seventh IDA replenishment is a very heartwarming gesture.

There are a number of important reasons why the additional contribution of $A60m to the resources of the International Development Association is required. First, it makes known Australia's concern at the inadequacy of the seventh replenishment. It will help to maintain Australia's overall measure of aid to the poorest countries, particularly as the additional funds will enable the International Development Association to extend its essential work as a concessional lender to all poor countries, including those in our region, rather than in a specific region of the world.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Development Association is a highly efficient and effective channel for disbursing major amounts of multilateral assistance to promote self-sustaining development in the poorest countries. Eligible countries for International Development Association assistance are those with an average per capita income of $US805 per annum or less. The majority of International Development Association resources go to countries whose gross national product per capita is less than $US400 per annum. In comparison, it is significant to observe that the Australian average weekly earnings for male employees for the December quarter 1984 was $390.70. International Development Association loans are interest free and can be repaid over 50 years with a 10-year grace period. Loans from the International Development Association are made to the poorest countries, which have a great need for development assistance. These countries are not normally able to obtain commercial or ordinary loans as the majority of them are not credit worthy.

SPEECH.PARA: Beneficiaries of assistance from the International Development Association have made real progress. Their per capita incomes have grown. Literacy and life expectancy have increased. Per capita income is only one of several criteria which have determined the allocation of International Development Association loans. Other criteria include a country's lack of credit-worthiness and access to commercial borrowing, its economic performance, population, and the availability of projects. The International Development Association at its inception concentrated on infrastructure projects; for example, transportation, power and ports. In the late 1960s food shortages in many countries prompted the International Development Association to have a greater involvement in the development of agriculture. Rural development projects have also been undertaken which are designed to raise the productivity of small farmers as a method of reducing absolute poverty and increasing total agricultural output. Much of the International Development Association's lending has helped to boost agricultural products in South Asia, spreading the techniques of the green revolution. As a result of those achievements India is now able to meet its own food needs for the first time in decades.

The International Development Association has increasingly been concerned with urban poverty and employment programs. It has pioneered programs to find affordable solutions to urban shelter problems. Industrial lending has favoured small and medium sized firms as a way of increasing employment. Water supply projects have increasingly stressed simpler systems. All these changes are part of an effort to reach the poorest people within poor countries and to design projects that will benefit them directly. Experience has shown that raising the productivity of the poor means more than providing them with productive assets. It also means increasing their skills and strength through education, health programs and other services. IDA's education lending, for example, has given increased emphasis to primary schooling, as well as vocational and technical training. Through the International Development Association, Australian aid is able to reach the poorest countries outside our region without incurring expensive bilateral aid overheads. Australia does not have the necessary infrastructure in many of the recipient countries to ensure that bilateral aid is used efficiently. Unquestionably, the International Development Association has a proven record of efficiency and effectiveness in administering its aid programs. The facilities of the Association also enable Australia to complement limited bilateral aid to large countries such as India. The World Bank is better placed than Australia to finance large scale projects and to develop and strengthen infrastructure within the recipient countries.

Australian external aid has increased from roughly $A700m per annum when this Government came to office to the present level of $A1,200m. This development has been in response to a variety of impulses. It has been an expression of humanitarian concern for the underprivileged. It has been an important element in foreign policy in that aid is a manifestation of our good will and our wish to foster mutually beneficial relations with the world around us. To be candid, our aid also has considerable commercial benefits for us. So Australia's aid program is a crucial element in our policy both as a trading nation in the Eastern Hemisphere and as a democratic country. That is why our aid contribution is equal to 0.5 per cent of national income, which puts us into the top half of the group of industrially developed nations who are the major aid donors.

The federal Government's target is 0.7 per cent, in line with the recommendation of the United Nations, and it is the policy of the Hawke Government-an authentic Australian Government-to reach this target as soon as possible. It is determined to pursue this policy, even against the opposition of some people who think that money can be better spent at home, for a most important reason. The grinding poverty of hundreds of millions of people around the world is an agony which is incomprehensible to us lucky Australians. We could shut our eyes to it, concentrate on our own fortunate lifestyle and standard, but as decent people we are refusing to do this. In any case, it would be dangerous if we did. We cannot expect millions of hungry poor people to remain satisfied with their lot. The growth of expectations as a result of improved communications makes that impossible.

I conclude with the eloquent words of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden), and I believe that these sentiments reflect a majority view of millions of Australians:
I support the passion and commitment of those who believe that the massive poverty of millions of our fellow men and women is an abiding stain.
But I also believe that the problems of poverty must be approached with generous sentiment, rather than easy sentimentality.
They will not be solved just by good intentions, but by rational analysis and careful planning.
This Bill represents an expression of rational analysis and careful planning by a government-the Hawke Government-devoted to national recovery, national reconstruction and national reconciliation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all aware of the need to help others, and the intentions of the proponents of the International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill are laudable. I am, however, opposed to an open cheque book policy. I would like to see aid provided in a different form. As people elected to this place we have a heavy responsibility to spend the Australian tax dollar wisely. There has been a growing realisation among certain elements of the Australian community that Australia's overseas aid-referred to as official development assistance-should place a greater emphasis than it currently does on commercial interests. Such a realisation formed many of the submissions to the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program, notably those of the Department of Trade, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Wheat Board and the National Farmers Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: Aid programs should perform a dual function. Not only should they encourage economic development in the recipient countries but also they should provide the maximum possible economic benefits to donor countries. These objectives are, in fact, mutually reinforcing. The argument is not that commercial and trade interests should be promoted at the expense of either the economic development of the recipient countries or the humanitarian considerations underlying the aid program; rather, I believe that the aid program must reflect a proper balance between the economic needs of the recipient countries and the economic interests of the donor countries. The current Australian official development assistance does not reflect such a balance and the aid program fails to meet the legitimate interests of Australian manufacturers and primary producers. Indeed, there is a widespread concern that Australia's aid policies appear to be developed in a vacuum without adequate consideration of the wider interests, such as the commercial interests, of the Australian community.
In my opinion there are five main reasons why the Australian aid program should be tied to the provision of Australian goods and services.

A direct linking of aid with commercial interests would help to expand manufacturing production and to revitalise Australia's economic performance. Such a linkage takes on an added significance in a period of economic recession and in the context of Australia's poor export performance over the past decade. According to figures compiled by the Department of Trade, Australia's share of world exports declined from 1.7 per cent in 1970 to 1.3 per cent in 1982. The Department has argued that this decline was due to Australia's inadequate export mix; its critical reliance on bulk, unprocessed commodities, the slowest growing sector of world trade, at the expense of manufactures and services, the fastest growing sector of world trade. This poor export record suggests that the Government should consider a variety of measures, including the use of aid, to help boost the country's export performance.

The tying of aid also helps to promote full employment. According to research carried out by the Department of Trade, exports generated 11.6 per cent of total employment-736,000 jobs-in 1980-81 and it estimates that every $170m of exports in 1983-84 prices generates 5,000 jobs. Thus, if aid were used to help promote Australia's exports, it would also help to ensure the provision of more jobs. The employment generating effect of exports is a critically important consideration when 8.3 per cent of the work force or, seasonally adjusted, 630,000 people are currently unemployed as a result of the economic recession and Australian Labor Party policies.

Participation in aid projects can familiarise Australian firms with business conditions in developing countries. Such a policy is actively pursued by other countries. For example, the United States of America Agency for International Development established a bureau for private enterprise in 1981 and it is estimated that AID activities and projects have generated some $US700m annually for United States firms.

The tying of aid to the provision of Australian goods and services assists the balance of payments situation. Untied aid in the form of cash grants constitutes a debit item in the balance of payments. Tied aid, on the other hand, eliminates such balance of payments losses by ensuring that the aid dollar is spent on goods and services within Australia. Hence export income automatically rises to compensate for the aid payment.

Finally, recipient countries might well benefit over the long term from tied aid. This argument rests on the supposition that donor countries might be prepared to offer recipient countries more under tied aid schemes than they would be willing to do under any other arrangement. Moreover, it is not necessarily the case that the political elites in Third World recipient countries are uniformly opposed to tied aid. In fact, for example, in mid-1983 the then Opposition Leader in Papua New Guinea, Mr Okuk, suggested that Australia should tie more, not less, of its aid to Papua New Guinea.

Most of Australia's major trading competitors, such as Japan, Canada, the European Economic Community, the United States and the United Kingdom, ensure that their aid programs carry a significant commercial orientation. Indeed, these countries regularly use aid as a form of subsidy to their export industries, notably those involved with capital goods and consultancy. Such policies reflect both a recognition of the close relationship between aid and trade flows and the importance attached to the role of private sector investment and its close links with aid.

Some of these countries, indeed, use their food aid to further their commercial and foreign policy objectives. The most notable example is the United States of America where Public Law 480 (1954), which provides the legislative basis for funding food aid, was explicitly designed to expand the United States international trade and to promote the economic stability of American agriculture.

Since the late 1960s the EEC has developed a food aid policy which tends to be used as a means to disembarrass itself of supplies of butter, oil commodities and powdered milk which are surplus to community requirements. Indeed, as the Australian Wheat Board concluded in its submission to the Jackson Committee, the policies of the main food aid donors merely reflect the fact that aid is just one means by which a multitude of national interest objectives are pursued. The Government should look into this aspect as a matter of top priority. Moreover, over the last few years there has been a growing recognition among these countries of the need to develop mixed commercial and aid packages in order to win development projects. Beginning with France in 1960, a total of 10 countries now provide mixed credit schemes by which an aid component is added to a financial package that supports a commercial bid, usually for capital goods, to be supplied to a developing country. Such schemes are in fact a reflection of the increased competition among trading nations in the wake of the international economic recession of the early 1980s. Although the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development prepared 'guiding principles' for these mixed aid schemes by which OECD members were required to confine mixed credits to priority development projects and to use such credits on the basis of international competitive bidding, these have proved ineffective in practice and have in fact been manipulated to suit some donors.

Given this situation, Australia has been forced, albeit reluctantly, to develop its own mixed credit schemes. In 1980 the former Liberal-National Party Government introduced the development import finance facility which provides grant funds for use in concessional export credit packages to Australian business for projects that are considered to have developmental merit. The Government also operates a development import grants scheme which provides grant credits for the purchase of Australian goods and services to South Pacific countries and the poorest countries in South Asia and Africa. The provision of such schemes as DIFF and DIGS has been welcomed by Australian business and trade organisations, notably the Confederation of Australian industry, as a step in the right direction.

However, it is obvious that the financial commitment to such schemes must be greatly expanded if they are going to provide any long term benefit for Australian business. For example, the total Budget allocation to the DIFF for the financial year 1984-85 amounts to $A16m. Yet the United States, in October 1984, approved a mixed credit package to help a firm compete for a single order of $US25m for locomotives to go to Botswana. The most far-reaching expansion and restructuring of the Australian mixed credit schemes has been suggested by the Department of Trade in its submission to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which is currently reviewing the Jackson report. I support this submission.

The Department of Trade has suggested that the DIFF funds should be increased immediately to 5 per cent of the official development assistance budget and by a further 5 per cent over the next five years. According to the Department's calculations, the DIFF scheme, geared to 5 per cent of the aid vote, would provide $A50m of funding which would assist export sales of some $250m of capital goods and consultancy services, while an expansion of DIFF to 10 per cent over the next 5 years would be enough to support sales of $2,475m-about a third of the Labor Party's expected deficit in each year over this period.

Moreover, the Department of Trade has also recommended that an Australian aid trade fund, on the lines of a similar Canadian scheme, be set up as an integral part of the aid program and be administered by the Department. It is proposed that such a fund would be allocated 10 per cent of the ODA budget and would fund aid-trade lines of credit, co-financing with multilateral organisations and aid-trade financing packages for bilateral development projects. Therefore, the Department has argued that at least 20 per cent of Australia's aid vote should support export promotion schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I thank the honourable member for Parkes for his support.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the fact that any dramatic increase in the overall level of Australian aid in the foreseeable future is highly unlikely, it is crucially important periodically to review the current mix of Australian aid among bilateral, multilateral and grant-in-aid schemes in order to ensure that it is appropriate to the needs of both the recipient countries and Australia. Two areas which, perhaps, need to be monitored fairly closely are Australia's contributions to multilateral organisations and its grant-in-aid support to the Papua New Guinea Budget. Together these commitments constitute over 52 per cent of Australia's official development assistance as opposed to 45.5 per cent for bilateral aid, excluding Budget support aid to Papua New Guinea. Australia's grant-in-aid to Papua New Guinea represents just over 30 per cent of its total ODA-about $A299m out of $A992.5m for 1984-85. Although it is recognised that Australia has, for historical reasons, a special responsibility for Papua New Guinea and that Papua New Guinea has particularly difficult development problems, it is widely admitted that it must become less reliant than it presently is on direct Australian budgetary support. It has been argued that once the present five-year agreement between Australia and Papua New Guinea, which covers the Budget support grants scheme, expires in 1986 the opportunity should be taken to increase the level of funds tied to the provision of Australian goods and services. Indeed, it has been suggested that the Papua New Guinea aid tied to Australian sourcing should be as high as 80 per cent. I strongly support this principle.

Australia's multilateral aid currently represents over 22 per cent of the total ODA-$A221.8m out of $A992.5m for 1984-85-and consists of contributions to international development agencies, international financial institutions-for example, the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank, et cetera-and United Nations agencies. However, such contributions have serious drawbacks in terms of encouraging commercial participation in Australia's aid program. In the first place, by supporting such a multilateral system, the donor country has little direct say in the disbursement of aid flows. This is one of the major problems with the Bill before the House. This basic fact is compounded in Australia's case by its relative geographic isolation from most international development agencies, which are located in either Europe or the United States of America. As a result Australia's involvement in the administration and policy formation of these organisations is not commensurate with its financial commitment. Indeed, Australian contractors and consultants generally do not obtain the level of business from such multilateral agencies that Australia's contributions might warrant. For example, out of a total of $US3.9 billion awarded by the Asian Development Bank between 1979 and 1983 Australia won only $US51m. A case could therefore be made for a greater proportion of Australia's multilateral aid contributions flowing to Australian business. The level of Australia's commitment to multilateral programs should be reviewed if such an increase cannot be achieved.

I would not want my contribution to this debate to be misinterpreted. My attitude is not intended to be harsh, callous or unfeeling. What I am seeking is a situation in which our aid reaches those in need and also benefits Australia in the process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to give my strong support to the International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill. The Government's decision to provide an extra $60m to the International Development Association beyond an initial $200m contribution to the IDA's seventh replenishment made last year has been made necessary by the Reagan Administration's decision to reduce its contribution in real terms. This is particularly regrettable, given the fact that the IDA has played such a key role in providing low cost capital flows to the poorest countries in the world. The United States of America, as the largest and richest nation on earth, has historically been the biggest single subscriber to the IDA, and its refusal to maintain this level of support will now seriously jeopardise the effectiveness of the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Development assistance is an important component of any government's foreign policy. Given that 80 per cent of the world's population receives only 20 per cent of the world's income, basic issues of social justice are involved in the foreign aid debate. I commend the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) for his stirring commitment to those principles of social justice so desperately lacking in the Opposition contributions to the debate on this Bill. I believe that on a broader issue there can be no lasting peace in the world without social justice. It is important in the context of this debate that we bear that principle in mind. During the last 20 years parts of the developing world have made good economic progress. Notable examples are Brazil, Mexico, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore, all of which have experienced extraordinarily high growth rates. Regrettably, the redistribution mechanisms within the domestic sectors of those countries have been less than satisfactory. However, the pace of development has been much slower and sometimes negative in the low-income countries. These countries remain highly dependent on financial development assistance from the industrialised countries, and the International Development Association is an important part of that assistance. For example, in 1980 the IDA financed 65 per cent of the deficits of the low-income countries, with the IDA accounting for 16 per cent of the total official development assistance to those countries. By contrast the middle-income countries, such as Brazil and the others I have mentioned, are able to rely more heavily on private capital flows, although this has now led them into deep trouble, as the international private banks have discovered to their mutual concern.

The crucial role of the International Development Association cannot be emphasised enough. The world's poorest countries do not have the resources to feed themselves adequately or to provide such amenities as clean water supply, transportation, health care or educational services that we in the West regard as basic minimum requirements for the enjoyment of a happy and healthy existence. Moreover, because of their poverty these countries are unable to attract commercial loans from international private banks to finance projects which may alleviate poverty. The funds provided by the IDA are therefore in a very real sense a lifeline for these countries. The IDA provides soft loans with 50-year maturities with a 10-year grace period and no interest. Their targets are the very poorest countries.

The contribution by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) concerned me greatly because he seemed not to grasp the point that we are dealing with blinding poverty. We are not debating the development of the Australian primary industry sector or the development of Australian industry; we are talking about social justice in the most desperate, gripping poverty-stricken parts of the world. But Madam Deputy Speaker, you would never know that that was the subject of the Bill if you heard the contributions from the Opposition side in the course of this debate.

In the 1960s the bulk of IDA funds went to infrastructure development, but this subsequently changed in the 1970s, when it was directed, as I have indicated, to the alleviation of poverty. Agricultural and rural development has received the largest share of IDA lending, up to 38 per cent, while lending for basic infrastructure accounts for 30 per cent of IDA's total lending. I think the track record of the IDA is worth referring to because since the organisation was created some 20 years ago 27 countries have graduated from or gone beyond the poverty level. They include countries such as Indonesia, Tunisia and Turkey, which are no longer within the lowest level of the IDA program. At present 51 nations meet the criteria for IDA credits; and 81 per cent of them have per capita incomes of $US410 a year or less, while 14 per cent have per capita incomes of between $US410 and $US795. The emphasis of the IDA seventh replenishment, which is to cover the fiscal period 1985 to 1987, is to be on Africa, where 20 of the 30 poorest countries are located and whose dire economic problems and low credit-worthiness with commercial banks require special treatment.

I turn again to the contribution, or lack of it, by the Reagan Administration. The decision of that Administration to cut its contribution in light of these circumstances is inhumane, to say the least; but, when it is evaluated in terms of the political objectives that are sought through this initiative, I regard the United States role as a disgrace which deserves international condemnation. Ever since the Reagan Administration came to power it has expressed an instinctive ideological hostility for the IDA and has persistently attempted to use its economic muscle and political influence to redirect the bank's activities towards more private sector oriented activities.

We have heard it all tonight from what the Leader of the House (Mr Young) refers to as cockeys' corner. Members of the National Party of Australia have put forward the same line as Ronald Reagan has put forward. They have not asked: 'What can we do for the rest of the world?' They have not asked: 'What small contribution might Australia be able to make to social justice throughout the world?' They have asked: 'How can we make a buck out of it?' In that respect it is important that we have regard to what the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program said on the question of direct food aid. I am sure that some of our friends in the National Party would seek to upgrade the role of direct food aid, because the Jackson report, which examined Australia's overseas aid program, opposed the growing international tendency to use such aid as a convenient means of improving the lot of donor countries by disposing of unmanageable agricultural surpluses.

That report also stated that the balance between bilateral and multilateral aid was about right and it recommended increased support for development banks, notably the World Bank. I suggest that, if this Parliament and governments of Australia commission reports to present a reassessment, an overview, of major aspects of government expenditure such as aid programs, it would do honourable members opposite the world of good actually to read what those reports have put forward. If they did so, they would not come into this chamber pushing their sectional barrow; rather, they would have regard to what is best for Australia's long term interests and those in the rest of the world who desperately need our assistance.

In regard to the role of the Reagan Administration, I do not believe that there can be any better example of the insensitive and harsh consequences of monetarist philosophy than is shown by its role. The provision of funds to the poorest countries to alleviate the most desperate conditions of poverty is opposed because such countries do not provide an attractive market for commercial lending. Of course, we have seen in Australia over a period of years the role of the Treasury and the role of the Department of Finance and leading individuals in those departments, including the former head of the Treasury, Mr Stone, who at one stage even opposed food aid to Bangladesh on the ground that in his perception it would be inefficient. I reject those monetarist views because I do not believe that they are either in the interests of the Australian people or in the interests of people throughout the world.

The Americans, in relation to their contribution, have reneged on an earlier promise to meet their share of commitments for an IDA budget of $12 billion. Originally, the World Bank President had proposed a $16 billion budget for IDA-7 in order for it to meet adequately the development assistance needs in its program. Following persistent approaches, a stand by the Reaganites and months of tortuous negotiations between the Bank and the United States Treasury, a compromise figure of $12 billion was agreed. However, even that was not enough to satisfy the Reagan Administration. That Administration has refused to give more than $2.5 billion, which effectively limits IDA-7 to a budget of $9 billion. This represents a 31 per cent decline from the United States contribution to IDA-6 and if inflation is taken into account it amounts to a 40 per cent decline.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the Russians giving?

—We have an interjection. The honourable member cannot restrain himself. We are talking about blinding poverty throughout the world, and what do we hear from this representative of cockies' corner? We hear: 'What are the Russians doing?' In this House last night we saw a good example of the integrity of Government members when it comes to even-handed criticism of the major powers in the world in regard to their role in international affairs.
