TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak in connection with a particular problem that has arisen in relation to poverty in some of the rural industries. I mention particularly the dairy industry, the sugar industry, and others such as the rice industry, where there is actually an absence of income support for people who are suffering rural poverty. Over a period of years there has been an opportunity, in the interpretation of benefits for unemployment, for some of these people who are self-employed ruralworkers to claim eligibility for unemployment relief provided they were prepared to leave their establishment and go out to work full time in other areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned this to the people in the head office of the Department of Social Security in Canberra. They realise there is a problem. Of course, the problem is in the interpretation of the Act under which benefits are paid. I believe that the industry should be providing the means of income support through some hardship benefit under rural adjustment. In my experience, it is very difficult for this to operate. The whole basis for such people being denied unemployment relief is an interpretation recently made which differentiates between a person being unemployed and underemployed.

If we look at the test cases being brought before the appeals tribunal we realise that there is a very fine definition but it is one which successfully precludes most farmers from being able to claim any income support in the form of unemployment benefit. Perhaps the best way I can demonstrate this is to read into Hansard a letter I have received from an industry organisation which puts these applications before both the Rural Adjustment Board and the Department of Social Security. The letter states:
There appear to be three problem areas with regard to the payment of benefits to growers:
1. The Department of Social Security classifies practising growers as 'under-employed' rather than 'unemployed'. In the case of an unmarried grower hardship cases exist.

I have actually taken one of these on appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal to try to get a determination. In this case it all depends what the words 'commitment to his farm' mean. The letter continues:
. . . details have been used by the Department to put forward a case for growers to be eligible for unemployment benefit between the end of crushing and the beginning of the next crushing season.
The second problem concerns the averaging of income. The letter states:

. . . At present if a grower has two farms and the farms are in different names they are not eligible to average their income between the two. For example, if a grower makes a $20,000 loss on one farm and a profit of $8,000 on another farm, the Department regards the income as $8,000 which, in the majority of cases, makes the grower ineligible for the benefit.
The writer points out:
. . . if both farms are in exactly the same names, averaging is allowed.
If there is any differentiation between the two partnerships, averaging is not allowed. The letter continues:

3. If a grower is paid a wage or salary from the farm (according to his tax return) the Department of Social Security looks on this as a direct income and may make the grower's spouse ineligible for any benefit even though the farm itself may have made a loss. In many instances the grower's spouse can put forward a projected return for the 1984-85 tax year which may enable them to receive a benefit. It appears if such payments are referred to as 'drawings' rather than wage or salary, there is no problem.

To explain this a little further, in many farmers' account books where some reward for labour has to be shown there is a debit to expenses and a credit to the loan side. However, in actual fact no money is paid in the form of a wage which can be used for living expenses. As I said, in such a case this can deny the benefit to the spouse of a farmer. The letter continues:

At present in Mackay about 80 growers' wives have received unemployment benefits but only four growers' applications have been approved. The growers' approval has, to our knowledge, been based on the fact that they have undertaken off-the-farm work on a regular basis during the slack season. Approximately 50 applications have been rejected but some of these have submitted projected returns and their applications have been reconsidered . . . . Some growers' wives who have applied for unemployment benefit-
and who have been ineligible-
have been referred to the age pension but with the introduction of the assets test they may be ineligible for both unemployment benefit and age pension.

I think the letter indicates that there is a real need for some type of income support which is positive and easily recognised and which can be quickly processed. At the moment most of the processing involves hardship on the spouse, who in the long run perhaps will not be eligible. Of course, the example which is often quoted to such people is that of the contractor who harvests the cane and who, at the end of the season when the machine is put in the shed, immediately becomes eligible, irrespective of the amount of income earned, for the unemployment benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I made a speech in the adjournment debate on the effects of the assets test. I noticed yesterday that in a speech the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) attempted in a rather lamentable effort to defend the assets test and he accused me of misrepresenting what is happening. I reiterate for the benefit of those who have not got the message that the assets test is causing considerable hardship and a lot of heartburn to many small farmers, and in particular soldier settlers. The case I was quoting-I am only quoting one of a dozen or more that are all similar-is a soldier settler who is on the verge of retiring. I make that point to the honourable member for McMillan who I am glad to see is again present in the House. In this case there is a son working on the farm. As is often pointed out to me, the son generally works for well below the minimum wage in the belief that the parents will hand the property on. The situation is that the farm is not earning enough income for two families. In the mail today I received news of one farmer whose average income over the last eight years was $3,000 a year. We have the situation where people have a property valued at around $200,000-some a little less-and when they add the value of the house on it-at the most $50,000-it gives them a total asset of about $250,000. The honourable member for McMillan is talking about showing compassion, yet he agrees that these people should not receive a pension.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us compare that situation with a city couple. There are people in the better parts of Sydney or Melbourne who have houses worth $200,000 and in some cases worth $300,000, $400,000 or $500,000. Their other assets might total anything up to $50,000, so their assets are at least equal to and in many cases considerably more than those of this soldier settler farmer and his wife. Yet, under this assets test legislation they can still qualify for a full pension. The honourable member for McMillan is talking about this assets test showing compassion, being fair and showing concern for these people. I do not know what he is going to say to the small farmers in his electorate because I think he is selling them out very short.

We have a situation in which there is a big difference. The assets test is totally inequitable because it exempts the family home. It leads to a situation in which people in the city who have assets at least equal to and often greater than those of the farmer still receive a pension whereas a person in the country with similar assets or fewer assets is being completely wiped out. As I pointed out to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who unfortunately is not here at the moment, the end result of all this is going to be that these small farmers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does he hate farmers?

—I agree. Why does he hate farmers? I would like to know that too. These small farmers will be forced into a position where they will have to sell their properties and no doubt, being fairly prudent people, they will do what their city counterparts are doing. They will go and buy a decent house in the city so that they will then qualify for the pension. What is going to happen to their son or daughter who wants to carry on the business.
—They will be forced on to the dole.

—They will be forced on to the dole. In these cases the pensions assets test will not save the Government or the taxpayers of Australia any money. In fact, it is going to cost money. We are not just talking about the cost to the taxpayers. There is the considerable worry and heartache that these people are going to suffer, having worked throughout their lives in very frugal circumstances. 'Frugal' is the word that has been mentioned in these letters many times. They have lived very frugal lives. Now they find that all their plans are just being thrown out the window by a government showing absolutely no concern for what they have done.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McMillan raises the word 'dishonesty' in relation to this matter. There is no question of these people being dishonest. They are honest taxpayers, when they have enough income to pay tax, which is often not the case, and they have been severely penalised because they live in the country and for no other reason. In talking to people in the Department of Social Security reference was made also to the question of hardship which the Minister keeps talking about. At the moment it seems that the Department has not issued instructions to its officers on how to administer this hardship matter, so that people in the Department are finding that they can offer no assistance to people on the grounds of hardship. It is causing officers of the Department of Social Security considerable heartache because they do not like people ringing up and breaking down on the telephone. They cannot do anything to help them and I think it is up to the Government to work this out too.
